questions.hint: This patient's sudden onset of stabbing chest pain that worsens with inspiration (i.e., pleuritic chest pain), recent immobility, tachypnea, tachycardia, friction rub, and lower limb swelling suggest a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism (PE).

questions.text:
For each patient with chest pain, select the most appropriate next step in management.
A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after the sudden onset of chest pain and lightheadedness. He describes the pain as stabbing in quality and radiating to the back. He has gastroesophageal reflux disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 42 years and drinks 6 oz of alcohol daily. He does not use illicit drugs. Medications include pantoprazole, amlodipine, lisinopril, and metformin. On arrival, he is diaphoretic and poorly responsive. His pulse is 106/min and blood pressure is 85/55 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Cardiac examination shows a normal S1 and S2. A grade 4/6 early diastolic murmur is heard best at the right upper sternal border. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia and left ventricular hypertrophy.
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous sodium nitroprusside therapy can be used to control hypertension in patients with an aortic dissection. However, the first-line medical therapy for aortic dissection is an intravenous beta blocker, which decreases shearing forces in the aorta by lowering the heart rate and the left ventricular ejection fraction. Intravenous sodium nitroprusside therapy alone will induce reflex tachycardia (via activation of the sympathetic nervous system), which increases shearing forces in the aorta and may worsen the dissection.

B) CORRECT:

The management of aortic dissection depends on the origin and extent of the dissection. Stanford type A aortic dissections require emergency surgical management; Stanford type B aortic dissections can be managed initially with medical therapies (e.g., blood pressure control). The next most appropriate step in management is an aortic imaging study to establish the diagnosis and classify the dissection. In patients who are hemodynamically stable, CT angiogram with contrast is appropriate. This patient, who is hemodynamically unstable (poorly responsive, tachycardic, and hypotensive), should receive bedside transesophageal echocardiography.

For patients in whom there is a high suspicion for aortic dissection, a beta blocker should be administered to control the blood pressure during concurrent evaluation of the patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous balloon valvuloplasty is used in the treatment of cardiac valvular disease (e.g., severe symptomatic aortic stenosis). This patient has aortic regurgitation from an aortic dissection, not aortic stenosis. Percutaneous balloon valvuloplasty has no role in the management of aortic dissection.

D) INCORRECT:

In patients with ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) for whom the door-to-balloon time is < 120 minutes, percutaneous balloon angioplasty with stent implantation is indicated. This patient's ECG does not show a STEMI. Percutaneous balloon angioplasty has no role in the management of aortic dissection.

E) INCORRECT:

In the setting of chronic chest pain, upper gastrointestinal endoscopy (EGD) can be helpful in identifying a gastrointestinal source (e.g., esophagitis) as the cause of the pain. However, EGD should be performed only after cardiac and pulmonary causes of chest pain have been ruled out.

F) INCORRECT:

Transthoracic echocardiography is unable to effectively visualize the middle and distal portions of the ascending aorta, the transverse arch, and the descending aorta. Accordingly, it has low sensitivity for detecting and classifying aortic dissections compared to other imaging modalities and is not the next most appropriate step in management for this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

Contrast esophagography with a nontoxic, water-soluble contrast agent can be used in the setting of acute chest pain if esophageal perforation or rupture is suspected (e.g., by plain radiographs). Esophageal perforation or rupture can occur due to foreign body ingestion, trauma, recent consumption of large amounts of alcohol or food, repeated episodes of vomiting, and after upper endoscopy, none of which are seen in this patient. Contrast esophagography has no role in the management of aortic dissection.

H) INCORRECT:

Emergency thoracotomy can be used to access the aorta for surgical repair of a Stanford type A aortic dissection. Though this patient has an aortic dissection, the classification of dissection is unknown at this time, so emergency thoracotomy would be premature.

I) INCORRECT:

Pericardiocentesis can be used in the setting of acute chest pain for the treatment of cardiac tamponade. This condition typically manifests with hypotension, muffled heart sounds, distended neck veins, and low-amplitude QRS complexes on ECG, none of which are seen in this patient. Pericardiocentesis has no role in the management of aortic dissection.

J) INCORRECT:

Chest x-rays are commonly obtained during the evaluation of acute chest pain and can show a widened aortic silhouette in patients with an aortic dissection. However, chest x-ray has a low sensitivity for detecting and classifying aortic dissections compared to other imaging modalities and, therefore, is not the next most appropriate step in management for this patient. Because of its low diagnostic yield, chest x-ray is likely to delay definitive diagnosis and treatment.

K) INCORRECT:

In patients who are hemodynamically stable, a CT angiogram with contrast is the most appropriate study to detect and classify an aortic dissection. However, this patient is hemodynamically unstable (poorly responsive, tachycardic, and hypotensive) and thus is unable to safely receive a CT angiogram with contrast at this time.

L) INCORRECT:

Serum D-dimer measurement is used in the evaluation of a patient with a low or medium probability of a having a pulmonary embolism (PE). Though this patient is tachycardic, he lacks other typical manifestations of PE, including dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, cough, and unilateral leg swelling (his Wells score for PE is 1.5, which indicates a low risk). There is no role for serum D-dimer measurement in the evaluation of a patient with a suspected aortic dissection.

M) INCORRECT:

Intravenous tenecteplase therapy can be used as thrombolytic therapy for a pulmonary embolism (PE) if the patient's bleeding risk is not high and the patient is hemodynamically unstable. Though this patient is tachycardic, he lacks other typical manifestations of PE, including dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, cough, and unilateral leg swelling (his Wells score for PE is 1.5, which indicates a low risk). Intravenous tenecteplase therapy can also be used to treat ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) where percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) cannot be performed < 120 minutes after the onset of symptoms or if PCI is unsuccessful. This patient's ECG does not show a STEMI. There is no role for intravenous tenecteplase therapy in the management of aortic dissection.
questions.hint: This patient has an aortic dissection, a condition that is typically precipitated by systemic hypertension and manifests with sudden-onset tearing or stabbing chest pain that radiates to the back. Aortic dissection may result in aortic regurgitation (due to involvement of the aortic valve), which causes an early diastolic murmur that is heard best at the right upper sternal border.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive swelling of her legs, shortness of breath on exertion, and abdominal discomfort for the past 3 months. She has also had nausea and decreased appetite, resulting in a 6-kg (13-lb) weight loss. She is being treated with paclitaxel for ovarian cancer and has had 2 episodes of pulmonary embolism during the past year. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years and drinks two glasses of wine daily. She appears tired. The patient is 164 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 54 kg (119 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctival icterus, protuberant abdomen with a fluid wave and shifting dullness, and 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. Lungs are clear to auscultation. There is visible distention of the jugular veins. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ovarian cancer is a risk factor for liver metastases, which can, in some cases, manifest with features of congestive hepatopathy (abdominal distension, ascites, jaundice) and/or peripheral edema if part of the hepatic venous system is compressed. In the majority of cases, however, liver metastases are asymptomatic. Moreover, they do not explain this patient's JVD.

B) INCORRECT:

Adverse effects of paclitaxel include hepatotoxicity, peripheral edema, and nausea. However, paclitaxel-associated hepatotoxicity is usually limited to asymptomatic elevations of serum aminotransferases; jaundice and ascites are not common. Moreover, the toxicity profile of paclitaxel does not explain this patient's JVD.

C) CORRECT:

Signs of systemic venous congestion (JVD and bilateral lower extremity edema) and reduced right heart output (dyspnea on exertion with clear lungs on auscultation) are consistent with right heart failure. This patient's right ventricular failure is likely due to recurrent malignancy-associated pulmonary embolism, which leads to an increase in pulmonary artery pressure and right ventricular afterload. Over time, this increased ventricular afterload induces right heart remodeling with consequent right ventricular dysfunction. In severe cases, patients may also develop features of hepatic congestion (e.g., abdominal distention, jaundice, and ascites) and/or gastric congestion (e.g., nausea and early satiety). Management of decompensated right heart failure includes oxygen therapy (if the patient is hypoxemic), fluid restriction, diuretic therapy, and treatment of any underlying cause.

D) INCORRECT:

Liver cirrhosis manifests with peripheral edema, nausea, early satiety, jaundice, abdominal pain, and ascites. Cirrhosis does not, however, explain this patient's JVD. Moreover, this patient does not have other characteristic findings of cirrhosis (e.g., telangiectasia, caput medusae). In addition, this patient has no known risk factors for cirrhosis (e.g., history of significant alcohol use, obesity, chronic hepatitis, primary biliary cirrhosis).

E) INCORRECT:

Budd-Chiari syndrome manifests with features of congestive hepatopathy (abdominal distension, ascites, jaundice), and this patient's history of ovarian cancer increases the risk of developing this condition (due to cancer-associated hypercoagulability). Budd-Chiari syndrome does not, however, explain this patient's jugular distension.
Image Description:

Budd-Chiari syndrome is characterized by hepatic venous outflow obstruction, most commonly caused by the occlusion or partial occlusion of at least two major hepatic veins (e.g., due to thrombosis).

The subsequent hepatic venous congestion leads to increased sinusoidal pressure, cellular hypoxia, and centrilobular necrosis, resulting in hepatomegaly and, eventually, a nutmeg liver.
questions.hint: If left untreated, this patient would also develop jugular venous distention (JVD) with inspiration or deep palpation of the right upper quadrant.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of severe chest pain and shortness of breath for 2 hours. Her husband says that she reported heaviness and pain in her left leg over the past week. Medical history is remarkable for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and chronic venous insufficiency. Two years ago, the patient had a deep venous thrombosis that was treated with low molecular weight heparin. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 42 years and quit 2 years ago. Medications are albuterol, formoterol, budesonide, and tiotropium. She is alert but appears distressed. Pulse is 115/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 89/61 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 84%. Examination shows perioral cyanosis and jugular venous distention. The left lower extremity is swollen and erythematous. ECG shows sinus tachycardia, deep S waves in lead I, pathological Q waves in lead III, and T-wave inversions in lead III. CT angiography of the chest shows a large filling defect in the left pulmonary artery. At this time, which of the following most strongly indicates a poor prognosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Decreased systolic blood pressure in a patient with PE suggests right ventricular failure due to obstructive shock, which is strongly associated with increased mortality. PE that causes persistent hypotension or right ventricular failure is therefore classified as “high risk” or massive PE. The risk factors most strongly associated with a poor prognosis (i.e., those that contribute ≥ 30 points to the final PESI score) are systolic hypotension < 100 mm Hg, advanced age, history of cancer, and altered mental status. Risk factors that contribute ≤ 20 points to the final PESI score are tachycardia (≥ 110/min), oxygen saturation on room air < 90%, temperature < 37°C (< 96.8°F), respiratory rate ≥ 30/min, male sex, history of heart failure, and history of chronic lung disease. This patient's risk profile would yield a class V PESI score, meaning that she has a very high risk for 30-day mortality (see “Pulmonary Embolism Severity Index” table).

Patients with persistent hypotension or shock (i.e., massive PE) should undergo reperfusion therapy consisting of either thrombolysis (systemic or catheter-directed, depending on the bleeding risk) or pulmonary embolectomy (if thrombolytic therapy is contraindicated or unsuccessful). Further treatment includes hemodynamic support (e.g., intravenous fluids, vasopressors in the case of shock) and respiratory support (e.g., supplemental oxygen, mechanical ventilation).

B) INCORRECT:

While sex plays a role both in the risk for developing PE and the prognosis of PE, it is men rather than women who are at increased risk in both regards.

C) INCORRECT:

Central cyanosis is a sign of hypoxemia and occurs if desaturated hemoglobin concentration is above 3–5 g/dL, which typically occurs at blood oxygen saturation below 80–85%. Although hypoxemia is associated with a poor prognosis in PE, perioral cyanosis alone (i.e., peripheral cyanosis) is a clinical finding that does not directly correlate with blood oxygen levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Sinus tachycardia is a common finding in patients with PE and is a compensatory mechanism for reduced cardiac output. While this finding is a predictor of circulatory shock and death in patients with PE, another finding is more strongly associated with a poor prognosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Although a history of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) increases the risk for PE, previous episodes of DVT do not affect the prognosis in patients with current PE. Concomitant DVT in a patient with PE, however, is a risk factor for increased mortality.
questions.hint: This patient's CT and ECG findings are consistent with pulmonary embolism (PE). The Pulmonary Embolism Severity Index (PESI) is a prognostic risk stratification tool that can help assess the risk of mortality in patients with PE by using 11 variables, including comorbidities, clinical findings, and patient characteristics such as age.

Appearance: in acute distress, unable to lay back; feels lightheaded 
Neck: jugular venous pressure of  8 cm H2O above the sternal angle; trachea is midline
Pulmonary: decreased breath sounds bilaterally; productive cough with blood-tinged sputum
Cardiac: tachycardia; split S2
Abdominal: obese; nontender to palpation; normoactive bowel sounds; no hepatosplenomegaly 
Extremities: mildly tender surgical scar on the right knee, no edema; tenderness and erythema of the right calf; radial and femoral pulses intact bilaterally
Neurologic: alert, fully oriented

Diagnostic Studies

ECG: sinus tachycardia; QRS duration 140 ms, rSR' waves in leads V1-V2, ST-segment depression and T-wave inversion in leads V1-V2

bedside echocardiography: mid-segment dilatation of the right ventricle, tricuspid regurgitation, increased pulmonary artery systolic pressure

CT scan of the chest: shown


Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pericardiocentesis is a procedure used to treat patients with pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade. Cardiac tamponade can manifest with dyspnea, chest pain, hypotension, and jugular venous distension. However, her CT scan shows a vascular filling defect consistent with PE, as opposed to a fluid-filled pericardial sac, which would be typical in a patient with tamponade. Furthermore, pericardiocentesis would pose a risk of myocardial or endocardial injury in a patient who does not have pericardial effusion.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's CT scan shows evidence of a large pulmonary embolism (PE). In cases of massive PE with hemodynamic instability (e.g., SBP < 90 mm Hg), thrombolysis with recombinant tissue plasminogen activators (tPA) such as alteplase is indicated. Because of the associated significant risk of bleeding, there are several relative and absolute contraindications to thrombolytic therapy. Surgery within the past 10 days is a relative contraindication, but this patient underwent surgery 3 weeks ago. Therefore, alteplase would be the most appropriate treatment. Anticoagulation with heparin, rivaroxaban, warfarin, or apixaban is also appropriate treatment for patients with PE. However, these agents are typically used in patients who remain hemodynamically stable.

C) INCORRECT:

Coronary angioplasty is used in the treatment of myocardial infarction (MI). MI can manifest with chest pain, jugular venous distension, and hypotension. However, her CT scan shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism. In addition, a CT scan is typically not diagnostic in cases of myocardial infarction.

D) INCORRECT:

Endovascular stent-grafting can be used in the treatment of type A (proximal) aortic dissection. Patients typically present with severe, tearing chest pain, hypertension, and asymmetric pulses. Hypotension, severe dyspnea, and cough are less common manifestations of type A aortic dissection. The patient's CT scan also shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism rather than a tear in the aortic intima, which would be typical in a case of dissection.
Image Description:

Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT angiography (chest; ECG-gated; venous and arterial phases; axial plane) of a patient with a history of recent weakness, vertigo, and facial swelling

The ascending aorta is dilated and a Stanford type A (DeBakey type II) aortic dissection is seen. The aortic arch and descending aorta are not affected. The right and left coronary, the innominate, the left common carotid, and the subclavian arteries originate from the true lumen (green overlay; false lumen is red overlay). Facial swelling is the result of venous congestion from compression of the superior vena cava (blue overlay) by the dilated ascending aorta. Bilateral small pleural effusions are seen.

Additional findings include sternotomy wires, a prosthetic aortic valve, atherosclerotic calcifications, pancreatic calcifications, and a small hiatal hernia.

LCA: left coronary artery; RCA: right coronary artery; yellow overlay: azygos vein

E) INCORRECT:

Piperacillin/tazobactam can be used in the treatment of pneumonia. Pneumonia can manifest with dyspnea and cough, and, in the setting of sepsis, even hypotension. However, jugular venous distension would not be expected in pneumonia. In addition, this patient's CT scan shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism rather than parenchymal infiltrates and/or consolidation, which would be typical in a case of pneumonia.

F) INCORRECT:

Tube thoracostomy is used in the treatment of tension pneumothorax, which can manifest with dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, cough, jugular venous distension, and hypotension. However, her CT scan shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism rather than air in the pleural space with tracheal deviation, which is typical in cases of tension pneumothorax.

G) INCORRECT:

Bumetanide is a diuretic used in the treatment of pulmonary edema. Pulmonary edema can manifest with dyspnea, cough, tachypnea, and jugular venous distension. However, her CT scan shows a vascular filling defect that is consistent with a pulmonary embolism rather than the findings typically seen in pulmonary edema (i.e., ground-glass opacities and peribronchovascular interstitial thickening). In addition, administering a diuretic could be detrimental to a patient with hypotension.
questions.hint: Orthopedic surgeries, such as a total knee replacement, often cause prolonged immobilization. This is a significant risk factor for venous stasis.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman reports progressive shortness of breath, a nonproductive cough, and pleuritic chest pain that developed several days after a long airline flight.
She has a temperature of 37.5°C, a heart rate of 115 beats per minute that is regular, a blood pressure of 80/58 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 88% while breathing ambient air. She is in mild distress and has inspiratory crackles at the left lung base, as well as mild swelling of the left leg.
Laboratory evaluation reveals a normal complete blood count and normal serum creatinine level, a brain natriuretic peptide level of 224 pg/mL (reference range, ≤67), and a serum troponin-T level (measured using a 4th-generation assay) of 0.9 ng/mL (0–0.03).
CT pulmonary angiography shows a large central pulmonary embolism at the branch of the pulmonary artery. A bedside limited echocardiogram shows normal left ventricular systolic function, a mildly dilated right ventricle, and mildly depressed right ventricular systolic function.
The patient has received two liters of normal saline in the emergency department and remains hypotensive (78/55 mm Hg).
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Administer therapeutic doses of low-molecular-weight heparin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tirofiban belongs to a class of antiplatelet agents named glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors. It is indicated to reduce the rate of thrombotic cardiovascular events (death, myocardial infarction, or refractory ischemia requiring repeat cardiac procedures) in individuals with non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome. It has no role in the treatment of pulmonary embolism.

B) INCORRECT:

Given this patient’s high-risk features, the addition of thrombolytic therapy is favored over treatment with only low-molecular-weight heparin.

C) INCORRECT:

Because this patient is not having an acute coronary syndrome, giving her a beta-blocker (e.g., metoprolol) would be inappropriate and could worsen her clinical status.

D) INCORRECT:

Given this patient’s high-risk features, the addition of thrombolytic therapy is favored over treatment with only unfractionated heparin.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation is consistent with a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism, and CT imaging confirms the presence of a saddle pulmonary embolism. The patient has hypotension, and her echocardiogram is consistent with right ventricular dysfunction. Elevated levels of serum troponins and brain natriuretic peptide can be seen with severe pulmonary embolism, especially when concomitant right ventricular dysfunction exists; their presence suggests an increased mortality risk in acute pulmonary embolism.

Because this patient's combination of features suggests pulmonary embolism with high mortality risk, aggressive treatment in the form of thrombolysis is indicated. According to current guidelines from the American Society of Hematology, patients with pulmonary embolism and hemodynamic compromise should undergo thrombolytic therapy followed by anticoagulation instead of being treated with anticoagulation alone.

Key learning point: Persistent shock due to confirmed pulmonary embolism is an indication for aggressive therapy with thrombolysis or thrombectomy.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man is hospitalized for antibiotic management of a diabetic foot ulcer. He develops dyspnea and chest discomfort shortly after being diagnosed with extensive femoral deep-vein thrombosis in the right leg.
His blood pressure is 81/64 mm Hg, his heart rate is 120 beats per minute, his respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 93% on 4 liters of oxygen by nasal cannula. His extremities are cool. An electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia with a new right bundle-branch block.
Two liters of normal saline are administered, but the patient's hypotension persists.
In addition to obtaining an appropriate diagnostic evaluation, which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Place an inferior vena cava filter
Perform cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acute dyspnea, hypoxemia, and hypotension in a patient with a large femoral deep-vein thrombosis are consistent with a diagnosis of a massive pulmonary embolism (PE). A massive PE is associated with persistent systolic blood pressure <90 mm Hg, evidence of poor tissue perfusion, or both despite adequate resuscitation. It is best treated with intravenous fibrinolytics (e.g., tissue plasminogen activator), surgical embolectomy, or catheter-based thrombectomy. The diagnosis of venous thromboembolism should be confirmed before starting fibrinolytic therapy, although obtaining CT pulmonary angiography is not always feasible if the patient is unstable or unable to travel to the scanner. Fibrinolytics are relatively contraindicated in patients with substantially increased risk for bleeding.

Key learning point: The indications for intravenous fibrinolytics (e.g., tissue plasminogen activator), surgical embolectomy, or catheter-based thrombectomy in a patient with a massive pulmonary embolism are persistent systolic blood pressure <90 mm Hg or evidence of poor tissue perfusion despite adequate resuscitation.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous heparin and subcutaneous enoxaparin are appropriate for treating a PE that is not massive or if advanced therapies are not available.

C) INCORRECT:

Placement of an inferior vena cava filter is appropriate for preventing recurrent PE in a patient with a contraindication to anticoagulation.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous heparin and subcutaneous enoxaparin are appropriate for treating a PE that is not massive or if advanced therapies are not available.

E) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography is not indicated in a patient whose likely diagnosis is PE and not acute coronary syndrome.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with colon cancer metastatic to the liver is hospitalized with acute dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain. Initial vital signs document a temperature of 37.0°C, a regular heart rate of 100 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 120/70 mm Hg, and a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 85% while he is breathing ambient air and increases to 97% with 3 liters of supplemental oxygen.
Physical examination is remarkable only for mild respiratory distress, with obvious discomfort on deep inspiration, and for 1+ right-lower-extremity edema with associated erythema. Cardiac examination is remarkable only for resting tachycardia; the pulmonary examination is normal.
Contrast-enhanced CT of the chest reveals filling defects in the segmental pulmonary arteries bilaterally. The complete blood count, basic metabolic panel, and serum troponin level are within normal limits.
Which one of the following treatment regimens is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Placement of an inferior vena cava filter
Thrombolysis followed by intravenous heparin and transition to warfarin
Subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin with transition to warfarin
Long-term treatment with subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin
Intravenous heparin with transition to warfarin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Placement of an inferior vena cava filter is not indicated in a patient with acute pulmonary embolism who is a candidate for anticoagulation.

B) INCORRECT:

Thrombolysis is generally reserved for patients with hemodynamic compromise or right ventricular dysfunction.

C) INCORRECT:

Historically, when a hemodynamically stable patient with cancer developed acute pulmonary embolism or deep-vein thrombosis, they were treated with a long-term subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH), which is associated with a lower incidence of recurrent VTE than warfarin. More recently, direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) have entered clinical practice and are now guideline-endorsed for first-line use in most patients with cancer and VTE.

D) CORRECT:

People with cancer are at high risk for venous thromboembolism (VTE) because of the malignancy-induced prothrombotic state, and VTE is a leading cause of death in people with cancer. Decisions about appropriate anticoagulation therapy in this population are therefore critical.

Historically, when a hemodynamically stable patient with cancer developed acute pulmonary embolism or deep-vein thrombosis, they were treated with a long-term subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH), which is associated with a lower incidence of recurrent VTE than warfarin. More recently, direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) have entered clinical practice and are now guideline-endorsed for first-line use in most patients with cancer and VTE. The evidence for the use of DOACs in this population comes from several clinical trials involving patients with cancer:

• In the SELECT-D trial, rivaroxaban was associated with a significantly lower rate of recurrent VTE than dalteparin, with similar rates of major bleeding.
• In the Hokusai VTE Cancer trial, there was no significant difference in VTE recurrence between patients who received 5 days of dalteparin followed by edoxaban and patients who continued dalteparin.
• In the Caravaggio trial, apixaban was noninferior to dalteparin in preventing VTE recurrence at 6 months.

The decision of which anticoagulant to use in a given patient with cancer should take into account the currently available data and specific patient characteristics. Although the convenience of oral dosing may favor DOACs, several other factors may lead clinicians to choose an LMWH. In this particular case, the patient’s cancer is gastrointestinal (GI), which may affect the choice of anticoagulation. Studies have shown that patients with GI malignancies are more likely to experience GI bleeding with rivaroxaban or edoxaban than with an LMWH; thus, an LMWH or the DOAC apixaban is preferred in these patients.

Other factors that may lead clinicians to choose an LMWH include:

• Clinical situations where there is a lack of data for DOACs, including patient populations that were excluded from or poorly represented in the DOAC trials
• Concerns about drug-drug interactions, especially with anticancer therapeutics
• Concerns about oral absorption potentially being inadequate in patients with GI toxicity (e.g., gastritis, enteritis) or in those who have undergone surgery involving the upper GI tract (DOACs are absorbed in the stomach and proximal small bowel)

Anticoagulation therapy is generally continued indefinitely if there continues to be evidence of active malignancy or if the patient has another strong risk factor for VTE; it is only stopped if the patient develops bleeding complications or requests discontinuation for quality-of-life reasons.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for acute pulmonary embolism in a hemodynamically stable patient with metastatic cancer is long-term anticoagulation; although direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) are recommended for most patients, those with gastrointestinal malignancies are usually treated with subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin because it is associated with a lower risk of gastrointestinal bleeding in these patients than most DOACs are.

E) INCORRECT:

Historically, when a hemodynamically stable patient with cancer developed acute pulmonary embolism or deep-vein thrombosis, they were treated with a long-term subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH), which is associated with a lower incidence of recurrent VTE than warfarin. More recently, direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) have entered clinical practice and are now guideline-endorsed for first-line use in most patients with cancer and VTE.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman with severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) reports a 5-day history of worsening chest tightness and dyspnea on exertion. She states that she has not had fevers, increases in sputum volume, or changes in sputum color. She reports no significant exposures, recent sick contacts, or travel. She has had occasional nocturnal dyspnea, which she associates with COPD symptoms. Albuterol does not clearly relieve or improve her symptoms.
Her heart rate is 110 beats per minute, her respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute, her blood pressure is 129/71 mm Hg, her temperature is 37.1°C, and her oxygen saturation is 96% with 3 liters of oxygen via nasal cannula.
The patient is dyspneic. She has a 1/6 systolic murmur and a slightly prominent pulmonic component of the second heart sound. On pulmonary auscultation, she has a prolonged expiratory phase and diminished breath sounds without wheezes or crackles. She has no pedal edema.
An electrocardiogram reveals sinus tachycardia but no evidence of ischemia. A complete blood count and basic chemistry values are within normal limits. The D-dimer level is 0.84 μg/mL (reference range, <0.5). Troponin levels are undetectable.
Chest radiographs are obtained (figures 1 and 2).
Which one of the following investigations is most appropriate to further evaluate this patient’s acute pulmonary exacerbation?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Among patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) who present with acute symptoms of dyspnea, approximately 70% of episodes are related to viral or bacterial infection. The remaining episodes are caused by other environmental exposures or other comorbidities, including myocardial ischemia or congestive heart failure. In addition, a meta-analysis showed that 25% of patients with COPD who present with worsening respiratory status have pulmonary thromboembolism, although the study did not establish a causal link between thromboembolism and the change in respiratory status. The presence of decompensated comorbidities, including cardiac and thromboembolic disease, has been linked to increased risk for worsening symptoms. Thus, in a patient such as this one who has a history of COPD and presents with new or worsening dyspnea but no clear trigger for an acute exacerbation — or in a patient with a history of COPD who presents with clinical features that are atypical for a COPD exacerbation — thromboembolism should be considered. A CT angiogram is prudent when thromboembolism is a diagnostic consideration.

Key learning point: A patient with severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease who presents with acutely worsening dyspnea but no evidence of an infectious etiology should be evaluated for myocardial ischemia, congestive heart failure, and pulmonary thromboembolic disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated levels of antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody are associated with a variety of vasculitic syndromes, including granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly referred to as Wegener’s) and eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly referred to as Churg-Strauss syndrome). These syndromes are unlikely in a patient who has a chest radiograph without opacities and no other signs and symptoms of these syndromes (e.g., acute kidney injury, sinus disease, or peripheral neuropathy). In addition, all of these diseases are quite rare, and other evaluations would be indicated before progressing to antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody testing.

C) INCORRECT:

Noncontrast CT of the chest would have limited benefit in light of a chest radiograph that showed no obvious abnormalities other than baseline emphysema. It would be useful for finding subtle interstitial disease, but that would not explain an acute decompensation.

D) INCORRECT:

Without evidence of infection, the yield of a bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage is very low. In addition, patients with respiratory distress are at increased risk of hypoxemic and hypercapnic complications of bronchoscopy.

E) INCORRECT:

If the patient had signs or symptoms of cardiac ischemia, a treadmill cardiac stress test would be indicated; however, it would not be appropriate to perform a cardiac stress test when the patient has new-onset dyspnea or is in distress. If there was concern for active ischemia as the cause of the patient’s decompensation, measurement of cardiac enzymes and an echocardiogram could be considered as next steps.

questions.text:
A 76-year-old woman with a history of GOLD stage 3 chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presents to the emergency department with dyspnea and cough. The cough has been producing a small amount of yellow sputum despite 3 days of daily outpatient treatment with albuterol nebulizers, prednisone 40 mg, and azithromycin 250 mg.
The patient is tachypneic and appears moderately uncomfortable. She is afebrile. Her blood pressure is 115/76 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 116 beats per minute. Her oxygen saturation, 85% while she is breathing ambient air, improves to 92% with supplemental oxygen (3 liters per minute). She has no jugular venous distention, murmurs, or gallops. She exhibits a prolonged expiratory phase with diffuse expiratory wheezes.
She is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. Initial laboratory testing shows normal leukocyte, electrolyte, and creatinine levels.
Arterial blood gas testing on supplemental oxygen (3 liters per minute) documents a pH level of 7.38 (reference range, 7.38–7.44), partial pressure of carbon dioxide of 38 mm Hg (35–45), and partial pressure of oxygen of 70 mm Hg (80–100). A chest radiograph reveals hyperinflated lung fields without infiltrates.
Which one of the following additional diagnostic studies is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Acid-fast bacilli testing of induced sputum

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Polysomnography is not an appropriate test in a patient whose presentation is not consistent with obstructive sleep apnea.

B) INCORRECT:

Without signs or symptoms of large airway obstruction (e.g., lung cancer), airway inspection by bronchoscopy is not warranted. Similarly, the yield of cultures obtained by bronchoscopy would be low given that the patient has already been treated with antibiotics.

C) INCORRECT:

The duration of this patient’s symptoms is inconsistent with tuberculosis, and her chest radiograph had no opacities, so acid-fast bacilli testing of induced sputum is not appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Spirometry is not indicated in the setting of acute respiratory distress, and the results would not broaden the differential diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

In a patient with signs and symptoms of a chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation that has not responded to treatment, pulmonary embolism (PE) is a possible cause. Meta-analysis findings show that up to 25% of patients hospitalized for a COPD exacerbation may have an underlying PE. In a patient with features that are not consistent with a COPD exacerbation or in a patient who does not respond to standard therapy for COPD, CT pulmonary angiography is the appropriate diagnostic study to evaluate for PE.

Key learning point: A patient with a presumed chronic obstructive pulmonary disease exacerbation that is unresponsive to conventional treatment should be evaluated for pulmonary embolism.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man hospitalized 4 days ago for treatment of diverticulitis experiences sudden onset of pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea. He has stable chronic kidney disease (serum creatinine level, 2.2 mg/dL; reference range, 0.8–1.3).
He is afebrile. His blood pressure is 110/74 mm Hg, his heart rate is 115 beats per minute, his respiratory rate is 28 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 85% while he is breathing ambient air. He is alert and oriented and is mildly uncomfortable from dyspnea. His lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. His left leg is slightly swollen and tender.
He is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. A portable chest radiograph shows no opacities and no cardiac or pleural abnormalities.
What should be done next for this patient?

choices.text: Obtain a CT angiogram of the chest
Obtain a ventilation-perfusion scan of the lungs

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An echocardiogram that demonstrates right ventricular dilation or hypofunction can help with risk stratification and treatment decisions in patients with pulmonary embolism, but treatment should not be delayed while this study is obtained.

B) INCORRECT:

CT angiography is relatively contraindicated in patients with impaired kidney function. However, even if the clinician in this case decides to proceed with contrast-enhanced imaging to obtain crucial diagnostic information, they should not delay treatment while awaiting the scan.

C) INCORRECT:

In a hospitalized patient with a high probability of pulmonary embolism, D-dimer testing is sensitive but too nonspecific to guide decision-making.

D) CORRECT:

This hospitalized patient with sudden-onset pleuritic chest pain, tachycardia, and hypoxemia has a high pretest probability for pulmonary embolism. In these patients, anticoagulation should not be delayed while diagnostic studies are pending. Therefore, the most appropriate initial management is to initiate intravenous heparin. Given the desire for rapid onset of anticoagulant effect in this case, the heparin should be administered as a bolus dose, which is then followed by a continuous infusion.

Key learning point: In a symptomatic patient with a high pretest probability of pulmonary embolism, anticoagulation should be initiated as soon as the diagnosis is considered and should not be delayed while diagnostic studies are pending.

E) INCORRECT:

Although a ventilation-perfusion scan would potentially confirm the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism, anticoagulation should not be delayed while the results of this study are pending.

questions.text:
An 85-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after a witnessed episode of syncope. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time, but she reports ongoing shortness of breath and chest pressure.
Her blood pressure is 75/46 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 108 beats per minute. Her jugular venous pressure is measured at 7 cm above the sternal angle. The heart sounds are normal. Both lung fields are clear on auscultation.
The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. A chest radiograph is unremarkable.
An electrocardiogram reveals sinus tachycardia. Bedside cardiac ultrasound reveals normal left ventricular size and function, right ventricular dilation with normal function, septal bowing, and a noncollapsing inferior vena cava.
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most likely to reveal the cause of this patient’s syncopal episode?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is used for diagnosing aortic dissection or aneurysm in unstable patients, visualizing atrial thrombi before cardioversion in atrial fibrillation, and identifying septal, valvular, or pericardial pathology when transthoracic echocardiography is inadequate. A TEE is not the most appropriate next test to confirm the suspected diagnosis of pulmonary embolism.

B) CORRECT:

The patient’s presentation of syncope and echocardiographic findings suggestive of acute right ventricular (RV) failure are most likely due to a massive pulmonary embolism (PE). Massive PE may result in acute RV failure, characterized on transthoracic echocardiogram by RV dilation (which can be associated with septal bowing), elevated RV systolic pressure, and either preserved function or global hypokinesis. CT of the chest with contrast (CT pulmonary angiography protocol) is the most appropriate next test to confirm the suspected diagnosis of PE.

Key learning point: A patient who has acute right ventricular failure with preserved function should be evaluated immediately with CT pulmonary angiography to evaluate for pulmonary embolism.

C) INCORRECT:

Tilt-table testing is indicated for assessing neurocardiogenic syncope but not in the setting of massive pulmonary embolism.

D) INCORRECT:

Cardiac MRI would confirm the presence of right ventricle dilation and can also evaluate for the presence of congenital malformation, myocarditis, or pericardial disease. It cannot confirm a pulmonary embolism.

E) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography is the test of choice to evaluate for acute coronary syndrome involving the right ventricular or left ventricular circulation but would not confirm a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism. There is no indication on electrocardiogram of acute coronary syndrome.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea. She has noticed pain and swelling in her left lower leg during the past several days. She has no preexisting medical conditions, and her only medication is an oral contraceptive.
On examination, the patient is afebrile. She has a blood pressure of 105/70 mm Hg, a heart rate of 115 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 93% while she is breathing ambient air. She appears mildly uncomfortable but otherwise not acutely ill.
Her lungs are clear on auscultation. On cardiac examination, her rhythm is regular, and she has no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. She has 2+ lower-extremity edema on the left.
She is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. An electrocardiogram documents sinus tachycardia without any other abnormalities.
A urine pregnancy test is negative.
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance angiography of the chest

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient’s presentation is much more consistent with PE than with myocardial ischemia. Therefore, myocardial perfusion stress testing is inappropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

In a patient with a high pretest probability of PE, a normal D-dimer result does not rule out PE.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents with signs and symptoms that are consistent with pulmonary embolism (PE). Her pretest probability of PE is high, as indicated by a Wells score of 7.5. The criteria for calculating a Wells score are listed below. This patient meets the first three criteria.

• Signs and symptoms of deep-vein thrombosis (3 points)
• Likelihood of an alternative diagnosis that is less than or equal to that of PE (3 points)
• Heart rate >100 beats per minute (1.5 points)
• Immobilization for ≥3 days or surgery in the past 4 weeks (1.5 points)
• Previous deep-vein thrombosis or PE (1.5 points)
• Hemoptysis (1 point)
• Malignancy treated in the past 6 months (1 point)

A cumulative Wells score >6 is associated with high risk for PE. The most appropriate diagnostic test in high-risk cases is CT pulmonary angiography.

Key learning point: In a patient with a high pretest probability of pulmonary embolism, the diagnostic test of choice is CT pulmonary angiography.

D) INCORRECT:

A transthoracic echocardiogram may show evidence of right heart strain in a patient with massive or submassive PE, but it is not a diagnostic test for PE.

E) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance angiography has insufficient sensitivity for diagnosing PE.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man presents with acute-onset pleuritic chest pain and associated dyspnea. He has no fever, chills, or cough. He has a history of prostate cancer and recently underwent surgical repair of a pathologic hip fracture. He states he has no lower-extremity swelling.
In addition to prostate cancer, he has type 2 diabetes, chronic renal insufficiency (baseline serum creatinine, 2.6 mg/dL [reference range, 0.8–1.3\]), an estimated glomerular filtration rate of 24 mL/min/1.73 m2 (≥60), and treated hypertension.
His respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute, his oxygen saturation is 89% while he is breathing ambient air, his heart rate is 104 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 112/72 mm Hg. His lungs are clear, and he has no detectable cardiac murmurs or rubs. His surgical incisions are well healed, and he has no lower-extremity edema.
The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. A chest radiograph shows no opacities. Initial laboratory evaluation reveals a serum sodium level of 134 mEq/liter (reference range, 136–145), a serum creatinine level of 2.8 mg/dL (0.8–1.3), and a leukocyte count of 7800 per mm3 (4500–11,000).
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate for this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has several features that make a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism (PE) likely, including the recent hip surgery, prostate cancer, and clinical symptoms that are consistent with the diagnosis, including pleuritic chest pain and hypoxemia.

For the majority of patients with a high clinical probability of PE, the study of choice is CT angiography. However, in patients with significant renal dysfunction, the decision to use iodinated contrast requires additional consideration. Contrast-induced nephropathy is uncommon in the current era of safer contrast agents, as evidenced by the fact that a number of recent studies and meta-analyses have failed to show that contrast is an independent risk factor for acute kidney injury. Nevertheless, in patients with significant risk for acute kidney injury, avoidance of contrast is appropriate if the diagnosis can be obtained with other testing. Risk factors for acute kidney injury include diabetes mellitus, preexisting kidney disease, and volume depletion.

Given this patient’s preexisting chronic kidney disease, he is at significant risk for acute kidney injury and should therefore undergo ventilation-perfusion imaging instead of CT angiography. This type of scan can identify a mismatch between blood flow (perfusion) and air entry (ventilation) in the lung using radioisotopes rather than iodinated contrast. Because it is unlikely to rule out PE in the presence of chest radiograph abnormalities, it should only be used in patients with a normal chest radiograph.

In a patient with an abnormal chest radiograph or only intermediate probability of a PE — or in a setting where ventilation-perfusion scanning is not available — the benefit of making the diagnosis with CT angiography far outweighs the small risk of contrast-induced nephropathy, and CT angiography is preferred.

Key learning point: The best diagnostic test for a patient with type 2 diabetes, stage 4 chronic kidney disease, and a high probability of pulmonary embolism is ventilation-perfusion imaging.

B) INCORRECT:

MRI can also be used to diagnose pulmonary embolism, but this test is often limited by respiratory and cardiac motion. An MRI takes longer to perform than a ventilation-perfusion scan, and there is more commonly a delay in obtaining an MRI.

C) INCORRECT:

In a patient with a high probability of pulmonary embolism, further evaluation with D-dimer testing is not recommended, as the false-negative rate is statistically high enough to preclude its use.

D) INCORRECT:

An echocardiogram may be useful in patients with hemodynamic instability in whom a pulmonary embolism is a high probability. In that setting, evidence of right ventricular dysfunction is consistent with, but not diagnostic of, pulmonary embolism.

E) INCORRECT:

For the majority of patients with a high clinical probability of pulmonary embolism, the study of choice is CT angiography. In a patient with an abnormal chest radiograph or only intermediate probability of a pulmonary embolism — or in a setting where ventilation-perfusion scanning is not available — the benefit of making the diagnosis with CT angiography far outweighs the small risk of contrast-induced nephropathy, and CT angiography is preferred. However, in patients with significant renal dysfunction, the decision to use iodinated contrast requires additional consideration. In patients with significant risk for acute kidney injury, avoidance of contrast is appropriate if the diagnosis can be obtained with other testing.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department (ED) with acute onset of dyspnea. He reports that he underwent an open reduction, internal fixation of a distal tibia and fibula fracture 16 days ago.
His respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 93% while he breathes ambient air. His blood pressure is 122/72 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 96 beats per minute.
CT of the chest with intravenous contrast demonstrates a segmental pulmonary embolism in the right lower-lobe pulmonary artery. An echocardiogram demonstrates no evidence of right heart strain. Lower-extremity ultrasounds do not demonstrate any evidence of deep-vein thrombosis. Renal function is normal.
The orthopedic surgeons agree that the patient can tolerate full-intensity anticoagulation without concern for bleeding at the surgical site. A dose of enoxaparin 1 mg/kg is given in the ED.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Initiate edoxaban 60 mg once daily and discharge home
Admit to the hospital and insert a temporary inferior vena cava filter
Initiate apixaban 10 mg twice daily, discharge home, and reduce the dose to 5 mg twice daily in one week
Administer tissue plasminogen activator 100 mg immediately and admit to a monitored bed

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A patient who has an uncomplicated provoked pulmonary embolism without hemodynamic compromise can be treated as an outpatient with apixaban or rivaroxaban, both of which are direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs), without any parenteral treatment. Dabigatran and edoxaban are alternative DOACs that can also be used in this setting but only after the patient has completed at least 5 days of treatment with a parenteral anticoagulant, such as fondaparinux, or a low-molecular-weight heparin.

B) INCORRECT:

Admission for intravenous heparin, insertion of an inferior vena cava filter, or thrombolysis with tissue plasminogen activator is not indicated in a hemodynamically stable patient with no major risk for bleeding.

C) INCORRECT:

Admission for intravenous heparin, insertion of an inferior vena cava filter, or thrombolysis with tissue plasminogen activator is not indicated in a hemodynamically stable patient with no major risk for bleeding.

D) CORRECT:

A patient who has an uncomplicated provoked pulmonary embolism without hemodynamic compromise can be treated as an outpatient with apixaban or rivaroxaban, both of which are direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs), without any parenteral treatment. Dabigatran and edoxaban are alternative DOACs that can also be used in this setting but only after the patient has completed at least 5 days of treatment with a parenteral anticoagulant, such as fondaparinux, or a low-molecular-weight heparin. DOACs are now the recommended treatment for patients with uncomplicated venous thromboembolism. The appropriate management of pulmonary embolism depends on risk level.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management of a new diagnosis of uncomplicated provoked pulmonary embolism without hemodynamic compromise in an outpatient is treatment with oral apixaban or rivaroxaban.

E) INCORRECT:

Admission for intravenous heparin, insertion of an inferior vena cava filter, or thrombolysis with tissue plasminogen activator is not indicated in a hemodynamically stable patient with no major risk for bleeding.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman is seen 3 months after hospitalization for a pelvic fracture requiring surgical intervention that was complicated by a segmental pulmonary embolism. She had no prior history of venous thromboembolism. She received treatment-dose unfractionated heparin while in the hospital because the surgeons were concerned about postoperative bleeding; she was rapidly transitioned to rivaroxaban at a dose of 15 mg twice daily for 21 days, then 20 mg daily thereafter.
Since discharge, she has been taking the rivaroxaban with perfect adherence, and she has not had any bleeding complications.
She does not currently have any complaints of chest pain, shortness of breath, or lower-extremity edema.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Continue the rivaroxaban at the current dose for a total of 6 months of anticoagulation
Reduce the rivaroxaban dose to 10 mg daily
Change the rivaroxaban to warfarin for an additional 3 months of treatment
Discontinue the rivaroxaban without further testing
Discontinue the rivaroxaban if a chest CT scan shows resolution of the pulmonary embolism

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An additional 3 months of rivaroxaban treatment (for a total of 6 months of anticoagulation) — whether at the current dose (used for initial treatment of VTE) or at the lower dose of 10 mg daily (used for VTE prophylaxis) — is not indicated, given that this patient has already completed the recommended 3 months of anticoagulation.

B) INCORRECT:

An additional 3 months of rivaroxaban treatment (for a total of 6 months of anticoagulation) — whether at the current dose (used for initial treatment of VTE) or at the lower dose of 10 mg daily (used for VTE prophylaxis) — is not indicated, given that this patient has already completed the recommended 3 months of anticoagulation.

C) INCORRECT:

Warfarin is a reasonable choice for outpatient anticoagulation for the first 3 months after provoked VTE. However, this patient has already completed 3 months of anticoagulation, which is sufficient for postoperative pulmonary embolism; there is therefore no indication for warfarin. In addition, changing a patient’s anticoagulant is not recommended unless there have been changes in the patient's medical status or preferences.

D) CORRECT:

This patient had a pulmonary embolism 3 months ago in the postoperative setting. The current recommended duration of systemic anticoagulation for a venous thromboembolism (VTE) provoked by surgery or by nonsurgical transient risk factors (such as leg injury, pregnancy, estrogen therapy, and flights >8 hours in duration) is 3 months. The most appropriate next step in this patient’s care is to discontinue the rivaroxaban without further testing.

Key learning point: The recommended duration of systemic anticoagulation for a provoked venous thromboembolism is 3 months.

E) INCORRECT:

Demonstration of resolution of the embolism by chest CT is not required.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman with no significant medical history presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset chest pain and shortness of breath. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive pill that she started taking 2 weeks ago.
Physical examination reveals a heart rate of 110 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 78/42 mm Hg in both arms, a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and a peripheral oxygen saturation of 89% while she is breathing ambient air. She is afebrile, and both lungs are clear on auscultation.
An electrocardiogram reveals sinus tachycardia with incomplete right bundle-branch block. Two liters of normal saline produce no significant change in her vital signs or physical presentation.
CT with intravenous contrast is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following initial management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Systemic thrombolysis with tissue plasminogen activator

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Catheter-based thrombus removal is an option in patients with a high risk of bleeding precluding thrombolysis or in patients who have failed systemic thrombolysis, but it is not first-line therapy for massive pulmonary embolism, especially given that the necessary expertise and technology are frequently unavailable.

B) INCORRECT:

A removable inferior vena cava filter can be considered for patients who have a contraindication to anticoagulation or thrombolysis or who have a high risk for recurrent pulmonary embolism and proximal deep vein thrombosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Catheter-directed thrombolysis, wherein tissue plasminogen activator is delivered directly into the pulmonary artery, is being considered more often in recent years, particularly in centers with practitioners trained in its use. No current data show improved outcomes with this technique over intravenous administration, and in general, administering systemic thrombolytics in an unstable patient is faster. Guidelines recommend systemic thrombolysis in favor of catheter-directed thrombolysis.

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic anticoagulation with intravenous unfractionated heparin or subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin is appropriate for pulmonary embolism or deep-vein thrombosis, but in a patient with severe hemodynamic compromise, thrombolysis should be the initial consideration, followed by systemic long-term anticoagulation with a direct oral anticoagulant or warfarin. Thrombolysis of a pulmonary embolism that is not causing hemodynamic compromise can be considered on a case-by-case basis, as a survival benefit has not been established in clinical trials, and current guidelines do not recommend it.

E) CORRECT:

A massive pulmonary embolism is characterized by either a systolic blood pressure <90 mm Hg or a systolic blood pressure drop ≥40 mm Hg. Thrombolytic therapy with systemic tissue plasminogen activator is indicated for hypotensive patients who are not at high risk for bleeding (e.g., because of recent surgery or risk for metastatic neoplasm to the brain).

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for a patient with a large pulmonary embolism and hypotension is systemic thrombolysis with tissue plasminogen activator.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old woman presents to the emergency department reporting a 4-hour history of acute pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea. Her only chronic medical problems are poorly controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes, for which she takes an oral hypoglycemic agent. She has had no recent hospitalizations or surgeries and has not started any new medications.
Her vital signs show sinus tachycardia with a heart rate of 130 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 84/50 mm Hg (which remains low despite infusion of 2 liters of normal saline), a respiratory rate of 32 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 90% with supplemental oxygen (2 liters per minute via nasal cannula). She has normal breath sounds bilaterally and regular tachycardia on cardiac examination.
An electrocardiogram reveals only sinus tachycardia. CT of the chest with intravenous contrast is obtained (figure). A complete blood count is unremarkable.
Which one of the following initial treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Persistent systemic hypotension (systolic blood pressure [SBP] < 90 mm Hg or an SBP drop ≥ 40 mm Hg) related to acute pulmonary embolism (PE) warrants initial thrombolytic therapy with tissue plasminogen activator (e.g., alteplase, streptokinase), followed by intravenous heparin and long-term anticoagulation. This patient has evidence of PE on CT - with filling defects in the right pulmonary artery and in the two main branches of the left pulmonary artery. Such PEs are called “massive” because they lead to hemodynamic compromise.

Unlike the use of thrombolytics for myocardial infarction and stroke, there are no strict time limits on when these medications can be used for PE associated with hemodynamic compromise. The general sense is that sooner is better, but there is not a time cut-off when thrombolytics are no longer considered.

Contraindications to thrombolysis include intracranial neoplasm, intracranial surgery or trauma in the past 2 months, recent hemorrhage, recent cerebrovascular accident, hemorrhagic stroke, severe hypertension (SBP > 200 mm Hg), any surgery within the past 10 days, or thrombocytopenia (platelet count < 100,000/mm3). The use of thrombolytic therapy in patients with “submassive” PE (i.e., without systemic hypotension) is generally not recommended but may be considered on a case-by-case basis.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial treatment for a patient with persistent hypotension due to acute pulmonary embolism is thrombolysis, followed by intravenous heparin.

B) INCORRECT:

Vasopressin may be used in the acute management of hypotension caused by PE but will not help resolve the underlying problem.

C) INCORRECT:

Persistent systemic hypotension (systolic blood pressure [SBP] <90 mm Hg or an SBP drop ≥40 mm Hg) related to acute pulmonary embolism (PE) warrants initial thrombolytic therapy with tissue plasminogen activator (e.g., alteplase, streptokinase), followed by intravenous heparin and long-term anticoagulation.

D) INCORRECT:

Epoprostenol is indicated for severe pulmonary hypertension and is not indicated for the management of PE.

E) INCORRECT:

Aortic repair (for aortic dissection) is not indicated in a case of massive PE.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old woman with a medical history significant only for hyperlipidemia presents with acute onset of intermittent, “achy” right-sided chest pain. The pain started about 3 days ago and is worse with inspiration. In addition, the patient has had mild dyspnea, as well as an intermittent cough that occasionally produces rust-colored sputum. She denies any sick contacts but recently returned from visiting relatives in Japan.
On initial examination in the emergency department, the patient has a temperature of 37.0°C, a blood pressure of 122/72 mm Hg, a heart rate of 112 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 93% while she is breathing ambient air.
The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. Serum laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (mm3)
10,500
4500–11,000


Hematocrit (%)
38

Platelet count (mm3)
250,000
150,000–350,000



Lactate dehydrogenase (U/liter)
156
100–190

7.8
5.5–8.0


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.0

The troponin-T level is within normal limits, and an electrocardiogram reveals sinus tachycardia. A chest radiograph shows a small, right-sided pleural effusion but no other radiographic abnormalities.
A diagnostic thoracentesis is performed. Pleural fluid analysis yields the following results:



Patient value

7.38

26,600



Lactate dehyrogenase (U/liter)

Gram stain, acid-fast bacilli smear, and cytology results are negative.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: Congestive heart failure with associated pleural effusion
Pulmonary tuberculosis with associated pleural effusion
Acute bacterial pneumonia with associated empyema
Primary lung cancer with associated malignant pleural effusion
Pulmonary embolism with associated pleural effusion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Effusions caused by congestive heart failure are almost always transudates and tend to be bilateral and associated with other findings on chest radiograph (e.g., Kerley B lines, cardiomegaly) and physical examination.

B) INCORRECT:

In pulmonary tuberculosis, pleural fluid analysis nearly always yields an exudate, but the exudate is almost never bloody, and the total protein level usually exceeds 5 g/dL.

C) INCORRECT:

Hemorrhagic effusions are not typically associated with pneumonia and empyema.

D) INCORRECT:

Malignant pleural effusions are also often hemorrhagic exudates, but cytology is positive in 60% of cases on the first sample and up to 90% of patients if three separate samples are obtained. They also tend to be chronic and large, and they rarely accompany acute onset of symptoms.

E) CORRECT:

Light's three criteria for an exudative pleural effusion are as follows:

1 Ratio of pleural-fluid protein level to serum protein level > 0.5

2 Ratio of pleural-fluid lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level to serum LDH level > 0.6

3 Pleural-fluid LDH level > 2/3 times the upper limit of normal for serum LDH

If an effusion meets one or more of the above criteria, the sensitivity and specificity for exudative effusions are 98% and 83%, respectively. This patient’s effusion meets the first criterion; in addition, it has a high count of erythrocytes, indicating that it is also a hemorrhagic effusion.

Pleural effusions occur in 30% to 50% of patients with pulmonary embolism (PE), and this patient is at high risk for PE due to her recent air travel. The effusions are usually unilateral and small. PE-associated pleural effusions are generally exudative, are frequently hemorrhagic, and can be associated with marked mesothelial hyperplasia.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with acute-onset chest pain and a small hemorrhagic, sterile, exudative pleural effusion is pulmonary embolism with associated pleural effusion.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old woman who is at 30 weeks’ gestation with her first pregnancy presents with new-onset dyspnea.
Her physical examination is notable for a slight fever, tachycardia, and a moderately swollen left leg. Laboratory testing reveals a leukocyte count of 6500 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000).
A lower-extremity compression ultrasound is positive for a deep-vein thrombosis in the left femoral vein.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Obtain CT pulmonary angiography, then start subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin if a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism is confirmed
Hospitalize the patient and infuse unfractionated heparin until 12 hours before delivery
Start subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin and discontinue it 3 days before delivery
Start subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin and discontinue it 24 hours before delivery
Obtain a ventilation-perfusion scan, then start subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin if a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism is confirmed

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The treatments for deep-vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism in pregnancy are the same, so when a deep-vein thrombosis is documented on ultrasound, no further testing with a ventilation-perfusion scan or CT pulmonary angiography is warranted.

B) INCORRECT:

Given its short half-life and reversibility, unfractionated heparin is reserved for patients who have a creatinine clearance <30 mL/min or who may need immediate surgery.

C) INCORRECT:

In anticipation of delivery, anticoagulation is usually stopped for 24 hours in patients receiving therapeutic anticoagulation (as in this case) and for 12 hours in those receiving prophylactic anticoagulation. This approach is possible when the timing of labor is known, such as in patients having elective induction of labor or elective caesarian section; it may be more difficult to achieve in patients who will undergo spontaneous labor. Therefore, some institutional protocols recommend switching patients to subcutaneous heparin when they approach term, because it has a shorter half-life if the patient goes into labor unexpectedly. Similarly, patients who are likely to have preterm labor are often switched to intravenous unfractionated heparin at 36 weeks’ gestation.

D) CORRECT:

The treatments for deep-vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism in pregnancy are the same, so when a deep-vein thrombosis is documented on ultrasound, no further testing with a ventilation-perfusion scan or CT pulmonary angiography is warranted. Subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin is the preferred treatment for most patients with acute venous thromboembolism. In anticipation of delivery, anticoagulation is usually stopped for 24 hours in patients receiving therapeutic anticoagulation (as in this case) and for 12 hours in those receiving prophylactic anticoagulation. This approach is possible when the timing of labor is known, such as in patients having elective induction of labor or elective caesarian section; it may be more difficult to achieve in patients who will undergo spontaneous labor. Therefore, some institutional protocols recommend switching patients to subcutaneous heparin when they approach term, because it has a shorter half-life if the patient goes into labor unexpectedly. Similarly, patients who are likely to have preterm labor are often switched to intravenous unfractionated heparin at 36 weeks’ gestation. The risk of intrapartum bleeding has not been shown to be elevated in patients who go into labor while receiving anticoagulation, but neuraxial anesthesia may not be possible given the risk of epidural or spinal hematoma. Anticoagulation can be restarted 6 hours after a vaginal birth or 12 hours after a cesarean section, assuming the patient is hemodynamically stable.

After initiation of anticoagulation therapy, patients should be monitored for extension of the clot, continued pulmonary emboli, bleeding, and adverse response to the heparin treatment.

Key learning point: In a woman who is at 30 weeks’ gestation and has a documented deep-vein thrombosis and suspected pulmonary embolism, the most appropriate treatment is to start low-molecular-weight heparin and then discontinue it 24 hours before timed delivery. Anticoagulation should be restarted 6 hours after a vaginal birth or after 12 hours after a cesarean section.

E) INCORRECT:

The treatments for deep-vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism in pregnancy are the same, so when a deep-vein thrombosis is documented on ultrasound, no further testing with a ventilation-perfusion scan or CT pulmonary angiography is warranted.

questions.text:
An 81-year-old man presents to the emergency department in January with acute onset of dyspnea one day earlier. He has also had a slight cough during the past day and has noticed that he occasionally coughs up small amounts of blood. He reports that he can typically walk several hundred meters on flat ground without being limited by his breathing, but during the past 24 hours, he has been too breathless to go about his normal activities of daily living at home. He has had no symptoms of upper respiratory infection or recent sick contacts.
His medical history is significant for hypertension, poorly controlled type 2 diabetes, stage IB adenocarcinoma of the lung that is scheduled for resection next week, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He reports adherence to his current medications, which include lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, metformin, tiotropium, and salmeterol. He has tried to take additional doses of inhaled albuterol without much benefit.
He has a 60-pack-year history of cigarette smoking but quit smoking 6 months ago. On pulmonary function tests performed 3 months ago, his FEV1 was 45% of predicted. He does not require oxygen at home and is up to date on pneumococcal, influenza, and Covid-19 vaccinations. Testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
On examination, he is afebrile and has a heart rate of 110 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 134/67 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 87% while breathing ambient air. He appears to be comfortable at rest, and cardiac examination reveals no murmur or jugular venous distention. Lung examination reveals inspiratory and expiratory wheezing bilaterally. Lower extremities are notable for 1+ edema to mid-shin, no swelling or calf tenderness, and a rash consistent with chronic venous stasis.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
5600
4500–11,000


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
10.8
13.5–17.5


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
29
21–30


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.1
0.8–1.3


Brain natriuretic peptide (pg/mL)
85
≤88


A chest radiograph reveals hyperinflated lungs with a round opacity in the right mid-lung field, as well as a small opacity in the left lower lung field, which is new from a radiograph obtained one month ago.
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate as a next step for this patient?

choices.text: Blood type and crossmatch for transfusion
Sputum Gram stain and culture, with rapid test for influenza

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography can be useful in PE risk stratification once a PE has been diagnosed. There is also value in assessing cardiac function when there is concern for a cardiogenic cause of dyspnea. However, this patient has no signs of pulmonary edema, no jugular venous distention, and a normal brain natriuretic peptide level; echocardiography is therefore unlikely to be a helpful first test.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient’s dyspnea is not likely to be from his anemia; therefore, planning a blood transfusion is not indicated at this point. Dyspnea from anemia typically does not occur until the hemoglobin concentration is much lower and would likely be more gradual in its onset. Further evaluation of this patient’s anemia may be indicated, but evaluation for PE is most important at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Although this patient’s COPD flare could have been triggered by a viral illness such as influenza or a bacterial infection, this is less likely in the absence of fever or leukocytosis, and ruling out PE is a higher priority. If the CT does not show a PE, it will provide helpful information for further evaluating the new opacity noted on the chest radiograph, and additional testing for infection can be considered at that point.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation is consistent with an exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Given the presence of malignancy in this patient, the first priority should be to rule out pulmonary embolism (PE) as a possible cause of the flare.

A useful tool to help determine the next step in evaluating a patient with possible PE is the Wells score, summarized in “Wells criteria for PE” table. The Wells score can be interpreted as follows:
• Score <2: Low risk for PE
• Score 2–6: Intermediate risk for PE
• Score >6: High risk for PE

Patients who have a low-risk Wells score (<2) are typically further risk stratified using the Pulmonary Embolism Rule-out Criteria (PERC):
• Age <50 years
• Heart rate <100 beats per minute
• Oxyhemoglobin saturation ≥95%
• No hemoptysis
• No estrogen use
• No prior DVT or PE
• No unilateral leg swelling
