• No surgery or trauma requiring hospitalization within the past 4 weeks
If all eight of these criteria are met, then no further testing is needed. If any of the criteria are not met, then a D-dimer measurement can be helpful; a normal value can help rule out PE and obviate the need for imaging.

In intermediate-risk patients (those with a Wells score of 2–6), a D-dimer level is indicated. If the D-dimer level is <0.5 μg/mL, further imaging is typically not needed. However, the full clinical picture should be taken into account for patients who fall into this group. Imaging to rule out PE may be appropriate for some intermediate-risk patients, regardless of D-dimer value. This may apply to older patients, those with cardiopulmonary compromise, those with a Wells score at the upper end of the intermediate range, and other patients whose clinical evaluation raises concern for PE beyond what is reflected in the Wells score.

Imaging should be obtained in all high-risk patients (those with a Wells score >6). There is no role for measuring a D-dimer level in these patients, as a normal D-dimer level does not adequately rule out PE.

This patient has a Wells score of 6.5 on the basis of his malignancy, blood-streaked sputum (i.e., hemoptysis), tachycardia, and lack of a better alternative diagnosis. Thus, the likelihood of PE would be high in this case. CT pulmonary angiography is the test of choice to evaluate for an acute PE and would also allow further evaluation of the new left-sided opacity in this case. In a patient with concurrent symptoms of DVT, one may consider Doppler ultrasound as well.

Key learning point: In a patient with a chronic obstructive pulmonary disease exacerbation of unclear etiology and risk factors for a pulmonary embolism, the most appropriate diagnostic test is CT pulmonary angiography.

E) INCORRECT:

D-dimer measurement to further rule out venous thromboembolism can be useful in a patient who is at low risk for PE according to Wells criteria but who does not fulfill all eight of the Pulmonary Embolism Rule-out Criteria (PERC); it is also useful in intermediate-risk patients. D-dimer measurements are not useful in patients such as this one who are at high risk for PE according to Wells criteria. Furthermore, D-dimer levels increase with age and in the presence of malignancy. In this 81-year-old man with known lung cancer, the D-dimer level is likely to be elevated even if no PE has occurred.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain that started suddenly this morning. She has a history of hypertension, osteoarthritis of the knees, peptic ulcer disease (PUD) related to nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug (NSAID) use, and anemia of acute blood loss. Her PUD was diagnosed on esophagogastroduodenoscopy during a hospitalization 2 weeks ago. At that time, she presented with syncope and melena and required transfusion of 3 units of packed red cells.
She reports that she has been avoiding NSAIDs since her discharge and has been taking a proton pump inhibitor twice daily. Because of general fatigue and knee pain, she has been spending more time in bed during the day than usual. She has no personal or family history of congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, deep-vein thrombosis, or pulmonary embolism.
She has a heart rate of 115 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 115/83 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 93% with 2 liters of supplemental oxygen, which she does not usually require. Her lungs are clear to auscultation, and she has a regular heart rhythm without murmurs. Her abdomen is nontender with normal bowel sounds. Rectal examination shows no blood or melenic stool in the rectal vault.
Laboratory testing reveals a brain natriuretic peptide level of 350 pg/mL (reference range, ≤62), a troponin-T level (measured using a 4th-generation assay) of 1.0 ng/mL (0–0.03), and a hemoglobin concentration of 10 g/dL (12–16).
An electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia without ischemic changes. A chest radiograph shows clear lung fields without interstitial markings, pleural effusion, or cardiomegaly.
CT pulmonary angiography reveals thrombus in the bilateral main pulmonary arteries and right ventricular dilation.
What is the most appropriate initial management strategy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In some institutions, catheter-directed thrombolysis or catheter-based mechanical thrombectomy is considered in the setting of submassive PE. There are no convincing data to support this approach, and these interventions are not recommended in the ACCP guidelines. If this patient with high risk of bleeding had hemodynamic worsening, catheter-directed interventions should be considered in lieu of systemic thrombolysis; this is a grade-2C recommendation in the ACCP guidelines.

Although thrombectomy is not associated with the same rate of bleeding complications as systemic thrombolysis and can therefore be considered if thrombolysis is contraindicated or fails, it is also reserved for patients who are hemodynamically unstable (massive PE), which is not the case for this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

The American College of Chest Physicians (ACCP) recommends thrombolytic therapy for PE only if there is sustained systolic blood pressure <90 mm Hg despite adequate fluid resuscitation (sometimes referred to as massive PE). This patient does not have hypotension and therefore does not qualify for guideline-recommended thrombolytic therapy with alteplase. Such therapy has been studied in some patients who have PE without hypotension — namely, those with significant cardiopulmonary deterioration or right ventricular dysfunction (sometimes called submassive PE). However, the use of thrombolytic therapy in these patients has not been associated with any improvement in survival and carries the additional risk of increased major extracranial and intracranial bleeding. This patient is already at high risk for bleeding and should not use thrombolytic therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) has a much longer half-life than unfractionated heparin and therefore takes longer to wear off. In addition, the anticoagulant activity of LMWH is only partially neutralized with protamine sulfate, making it harder to reverse should that be required.

D) CORRECT:

Anticoagulation should be considered carefully in a patient with a high risk for bleeding. This patient recently had hemodynamically significant upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding from nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug use and is at high risk for recurrent GI bleeding. Unfractionated heparin is the most appropriate initial choice of anticoagulation in this setting because of its short half-life (about one hour) and its reversibility. If the patient were to experience significant GI bleeding after starting anticoagulation, the unfractionated heparin could be stopped, or protamine sulfate could be given to reverse its effects.

The American College of Chest Physicians (ACCP) recommends thrombolytic therapy for PE only if there is sustained systolic blood pressure <90 mm Hg despite adequate fluid resuscitation (sometimes referred to as massive PE). This patient does not have hypotension and therefore does not qualify for guideline-recommended thrombolytic therapy with alteplase. Such therapy has been studied in some patients who have PE without hypotension — namely, those with significant cardiopulmonary deterioration or right ventricular dysfunction (sometimes called submassive PE). However, the use of thrombolytic therapy in these patients has not been associated with any improvement in survival and carries the additional risk of increased major extracranial and intracranial bleeding. This patient is already at high risk for bleeding and should not use thrombolytic therapy.

Key learning point: In a patient with a high risk for bleeding and a submassive pulmonary embolism, the most appropriate initial anticoagulation therapy is continuous infusion of unfractionated heparin.

E) INCORRECT:

Apixaban would be an appropriate choice of anticoagulation in a patient with pulmonary embolism (PE) who had a low risk for hemodynamic decompensation and low risk for bleeding. In this patient with a high risk for bleeding, apixaban is not preferable because of its long half-life and lack of easy reversibility.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea. She has noticed pain and swelling in her left lower leg during the past several days. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. She has a blood pressure of 105/70 mm Hg, a heart rate of 115 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 93% while she is breathing ambient air. Her lungs are clear on auscultation. On cardiac examination, her rhythm is regular. She has 2+ lower-extremity edema on the left. An electrocardiogram documents sinus tachycardia. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance angiography of the chest

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient’s presentation is much more consistent with PE than with myocardial ischemia. Therefore, myocardial perfusion stress testing is inappropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

In a patient with a high pretest probability of PE, a normal D-dimer result does not rule out PE.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's pretest probability of PE is high, as indicated by a Wells score of 7.5. The criteria for calculating a Wells score are listed below. This patient meets the first three criteria.

• Signs and symptoms of deep-vein thrombosis (3 points)
• Likelihood of an alternative diagnosis that is less than or equal to that of PE (3 points)
• Heart rate >100 beats per minute (1.5 points)
• Immobilization for ≥3 days or surgery in the past 4 weeks (1.5 points)
• Previous deep-vein thrombosis or PE (1.5 points)
• Hemoptysis (1 point)
• Malignancy treated in the past 6 months (1 point)

A cumulative Wells score >6 is associated with high risk for PE. The most appropriate diagnostic test in high-risk cases is CT pulmonary angiography.

Key learning point: In a patient with a high pretest probability of pulmonary embolism, the diagnostic test of choice is CT pulmonary angiography.

D) INCORRECT:

A transthoracic echocardiogram may show evidence of right heart strain in a patient with massive or submassive PE, but it is not a diagnostic test for PE.

E) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance angiography has insufficient sensitivity for diagnosing PE.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs and symptoms that are consistent with pulmonary embolism (PE).

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman presents to the emergency department reporting a 4-hour history of acute pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea. Her only chronic medical problems are poorly controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes. Her vital signs show a heart rate of 130 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 84/50 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 32 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 90% with supplemental oxygen. She has regular tachycardia on cardiac examination. An electrocardiogram reveals only sinus tachycardia. CT of the chest with intravenous contrast is obtained (figure). Which one of the following initial treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Persistent systemic hypotension (systolic blood pressure [SBP] < 90 mm Hg or an SBP drop ≥ 40 mm Hg) related to acute pulmonary embolism (PE) warrants initial thrombolytic therapy with tissue plasminogen activator (e.g., alteplase, streptokinase), followed by intravenous heparin and long-term anticoagulation. This patient has evidence of PE on CT - with filling defects in the right pulmonary artery and in the two main branches of the left pulmonary artery.

Contraindications to thrombolysis include intracranial neoplasm, intracranial surgery or trauma in the past 2 months, recent hemorrhage, recent cerebrovascular accident, hemorrhagic stroke, severe hypertension (SBP > 200 mm Hg), any surgery within the past 10 days, or thrombocytopenia (platelet count < 100,000/mm3).

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial treatment for a patient with persistent hypotension due to acute pulmonary embolism is thrombolysis, followed by intravenous heparin.

B) INCORRECT:

Vasopressin may be used in the acute management of hypotension caused by PE but will not help resolve the underlying problem.

C) INCORRECT:

Persistent systemic hypotension (systolic blood pressure [SBP] <90 mm Hg or an SBP drop ≥40 mm Hg) related to acute pulmonary embolism (PE) warrants initial thrombolytic therapy with tissue plasminogen activator (e.g., alteplase, streptokinase), followed by intravenous heparin and long-term anticoagulation.

D) INCORRECT:

Epoprostenol is indicated for severe pulmonary hypertension and is not indicated for the management of PE.

E) INCORRECT:

Aortic repair (for aortic dissection) is not indicated in a case of massive PE.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with a history of subarachnoid hemorrhage is brought to the emergency department because of shortness of breath and sharp chest pain that worsens on inspiration. She underwent surgery for a hip fracture 3 weeks ago. Her pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 112/74 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. The lungs are clear to auscultation and there is no jugular venous distention. A ventilation and perfusion scan shows a small perfusion defect in the left lower lung. Which of the following pharmacotherapies is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Warfarin, a vitamin K epoxide reductase inhibitor, is used for long-term anticoagulation (e.g., in heart valve damage, atrial fibrillation, arrhythmias, and post-MI). Warfarin prevents further γ-carboxylation of vitamin K-dependent coagulation factors, but the anticoagulative effect is not immediate; anticoagulation therapy for pulmonary embolism must be started immediately.

B) INCORRECT:

Low-dose aspirin, a COX 1 and 2 inhibitor, is used in the management of cardiovascular events (e.g., acute MI, angina) and for primary and secondary prophylaxis of cardiovascular disease. It is not, however, used for initial treatment of pulmonary embolism.

C) INCORRECT:

Clopidogrel, an irreversible ADP receptor inhibitor, may be used in the treatment of acute coronary syndrome and peripheral arterial disease as well as in the prevention of ischemic stroke. It is not, however, used for initial treatment of pulmonary embolism.

D) INCORRECT:

Alteplase, a recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), is used in the treatment of acute coronary syndrome, pulmonary embolism, and ischemic stroke. Fibrinolysis may be necessary for massive, life-threatening pulmonary embolism, which can cause hypotension or hemodynamic instability. This patient does not present with signs of severe pulmonary embolism. In addition, her history of subarachnoid hemorrhage is an absolute contraindication to treatment with tPA.

E) CORRECT:

Heparin is indicated as initial anticoagulation therapy in patients with pulmonary embolism, thrombosis, unstable angina pectoris, and disseminated intravascular coagulation. Two forms of heparin in clinical use are low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) and unfractionated heparin (UFH). LMWH is preferred because it binds selectively to antithrombin III and has a lower risk of side effects.
questions.hint: This patient's chest pain and dyspnea in combination with her recent surgery (suggestive of immobilization) and perfusion defect makes a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism very likely.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of midsternal chest pain, shortness of breath, and cough with bloody sputum for the past 3 hours. The pain worsens when taking deep breaths. The patient has a history of hypertension. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. Current medications include an oral contraceptive and enalapril. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Physical examination shows decreased breath sounds over the left lung base and calf pain, swelling, and erythema in the right leg. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Thrombus in the left atrium on TEE
Diffuse fluffy bilateral lung infiltrates on x-ray of the chest
Wedge-shaped opacity on CT scan of the chest
Decreased expiratory flow on peak flow meter

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thrombus formation in the left atrium most commonly occurs in patients with atrial fibrillation (A-fib), which causes abnormal contraction of the atrium leading to stasis of blood. While this patient has some risk factors for A-fib (hypertension), her presentation is not consistent with this diagnosis. A-fib is usually asymptomatic, but it can manifest with weakness, fatigue, and lightheadedness. Pleuritic chest pain and hemoptysis are not common features of this diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Widespread ST elevation and PR-segment depression on ECG suggest acute pericarditis, which manifests with pleuritic chest pain. However, patients with pericarditis will often have a prodrome of fever, malaise, and myalgias, and the pain is typically relieved by sitting or leaning forward. A friction rub is also common on cardiac auscultation. Lastly, pericarditis would not cause hemoptysis nor explain this patient's calf pain.

C) INCORRECT:

The presence of diffuse, fluffy (alveolar), bilateral lung infiltrates on chest x-ray is suggestive of pulmonary edema. In a previously healthy adult without known cardiac disease or other heart failure symptoms (e.g., peripheral edema, jugular venous distension, orthopnea), this finding would be concerning for ARDS. This condition could explain this patient's cough and dyspnea, but ARDS also causes severe respiratory distress, including even more marked tachypnea and hypoxia than reported here, and often an altered mental status. Lastly, ARDS would cause diffuse crackles on auscultation.

D) CORRECT:

This patient presents with sudden onset of cough and dyspnea, hypoxemia, tachycardia, low-grade fever, decreased breath sounds (due to pleural effusion), and features of DVT, raising suspicion for pulmonary embolism (PE). Hemoptysis and pleuritic chest pain further suggest that PE is complicated by pulmonary infarction, which occurs when the thrombus occludes a smaller segmental artery, resulting in inflammation of the lung parenchyma. The typical CT finding in patients with pulmonary infarction caused by PE is a wedge-shaped opacity near the pleura that does not enhance with contrast. The apex of the wedge is closest to the site of the arterial occlusion, with a triangular area of nonperfusion where the downstream vascular supply is cut off. A wedge-shaped opacity may very rarely be seen on chest x-ray in patients with pulmonary embolism; this radiographic finding is also referred to as Hampton hump.

The imaging modality of choice to confirm PE is CT pulmonary angiography, which shows a filling defect of the obstructed pulmonary arteries. This confirmatory finding is also seen in patients without concomitant pulmonary infarction.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (left; lateral view) and CT angiography (right; sagittal plane) of a patient with right thoracic and flank pain, intermittent cough, and blood-tinged sputum

A peripheral opacity (green overlay) seen on the chest radiograph in the posterior basal segment of the right lower lobe correlates with a heterogeneous area of opacification on the sagittal image of the CT angiogram. A wedge-shaped region of consolidation on the CT image indicates ischemic pulmonary hemorrhage or infarction. An embolus (hypodense filling defect; white arrow) is visible within the contrast-enhanced posterior basal segmental pulmonary artery.

E) INCORRECT:

Peak expiratory flow rate is decreased in obstructive lung disease, and peak flow meter measurement is often used as a diagnostic and prognostic tool in patients presenting with acute asthma exacerbations. Both asthma and COPD can cause dyspnea and cough, as well as increase the risk of respiratory infection. However, the sudden onset of symptoms without preceding episodic or chronic symptoms makes these diagnoses less likely, and this patient's pleuritic chest pain and hemoptysis would not be consistent with either asthma or COPD.
questions.hint: Calf pain, swelling, and erythema suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT), for which the patient's history of smoking and oral contraceptive use are risk factors.

questions.text: A previously healthy 35-year-old woman comes to the office because of a sudden onset of difficulty breathing that began when she woke up that morning. She also reports chest pain. She has no history of serious illness. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 93%. Physical examination is unremarkable. ECG shows a regular sinus rhythm. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. In addition to oxygen supplementation, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the work-up of pulmonary embolism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The A-a gradient, obtained from an arterial blood gas analysis, can be used to help identify the underlying pathophysiology of hypoxemia (e.g., shunt, V/Q mismatch, etc). While the PaO2 is typically low in patients with PE, this is neither a sensitive nor specific test and is not considered useful for the diagnosis of PE.

B) INCORRECT:

CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA) is the best definitive diagnostic test for PE. This contrast-enhanced imaging study is both sensitive and specific in diagnosing intraluminal filling defects in the pulmonary arteries but is also associated with certain risks (e.g., contrast-induced nephropathy). CTPA would be the next step in management for a hemodynamically stable patient with a high pretest probability of PE.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's Wells score for PE is 3, meaning that PE is more likely than other diagnoses but that no other Wells criteria for PE (e.g., tachycardia, hemoptysis, clinical symptoms of DVT) are fulfilled (see “Wells criteria for pulmonary embolism” table). This patient's modified Wells score indicates that PE is unlikely (i.e., a modified Wells score ≤ 4). In patients with suspected PE but a pretest probability of an unlikely diagnosis, clinical assessment should be followed by D-dimer measurement because normal D-dimer values rule out the diagnosis. In patients with elevated D-dimer values, further testing with CTPA or V/Q scan is required to confirm or exclude PE.

Key learning point: In patients with low pretest probability for pulmonary embolism, a normal D-dimer level effectively rules out the diagnosis and should be the initial test.
Image Description:

CTPA: computer tomography pulmonary angiogram
PE: pulmonary embolism
PERC: Pulmonary Embolism Rule-out Criteria
PTP: pretest probability
RV: right ventricle
V/Q scan: ventilation/perfusion scan

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary angiography is no longer routinely used to diagnose PE and is only recommended if a patient has a high pretest probability of PE and CT angiography is unavailable.

E) INCORRECT:

Ventilation and perfusion scintigraphy (V/Q scan) can be used to diagnose patients with a high pretest probability of PE, but who have contraindications to CT angiography. A perfusion failure in a normally ventilated pulmonary area (mismatch) is highly suggestive of PE.
questions.hint: In patients with suspected PE, externally validated decision tools such as the Wells score should be used to assess the pretest probability.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the office because of progressive swelling of her legs, shortness of breath on exertion, and abdominal discomfort for the past 3 months. She has also had nausea and decreased appetite. She is being treated with paclitaxel for ovarian cancer and has had 2 episodes of pulmonary embolism during the past year. She does not drink alcoholic beverages or use other substances. BMI is 20 kg/m2. Pulse is 115/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Examination shows a protuberant abdomen with a fluid wave and shifting dullness, and 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. There is visible distention of the jugular veins. The remainder of the physical examination, including lung auscultation, shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ovarian cancer is a risk factor for liver metastases, which can, in some cases, manifest with features of congestive hepatopathy (abdominal distension and ascites) and/or peripheral edema if part of the hepatic venous system is compressed. In the majority of cases, however, liver metastases are asymptomatic. Moreover, they do not explain this patient's jugular venous distention.

B) INCORRECT:

Adverse effects of paclitaxel include hepatotoxicity, peripheral edema, and nausea. However, paclitaxel-associated hepatotoxicity is usually limited to asymptomatic elevations of serum aminotransferases; abdominal distension and ascites are not common. Moreover, the toxicity profile of paclitaxel does not explain this patient's jugular venous distention.

C) CORRECT:

Signs of systemic venous congestion (JVD and bilateral lower extremity edema) and reduced right heart output (dyspnea on exertion with clear lungs on auscultation) are consistent with right heart failure. This patient's right ventricular failure is likely due to recurrent malignancy-associated pulmonary embolism, which leads to an increase in pulmonary artery pressure and right ventricular afterload. Over time, this increased ventricular afterload induces right heart remodeling with consequent right ventricular dysfunction. In severe cases, patients may also develop features of hepatic congestion (e.g., abdominal distention and ascites) and/or gastric congestion (e.g., nausea and early satiety). Management of decompensated right heart failure includes oxygen therapy (if the patient is hypoxemic), fluid restriction, diuretic therapy, and treatment of any underlying cause.

D) INCORRECT:

Liver cirrhosis manifests with peripheral edema, nausea, early satiety, abdominal pain, and ascites. Cirrhosis does not, however, explain this patient's jugular venous distention. Moreover, this patient does not have other characteristic findings of cirrhosis (e.g., jaundice, telangiectasia, caput medusae). In addition, this patient has no known risk factors for cirrhosis (e.g., history of significant alcohol use, obesity, chronic hepatitis, primary biliary cirrhosis).

E) INCORRECT:

Budd-Chiari syndrome manifests with features of congestive hepatopathy (abdominal distension and ascites), and this patient's history of ovarian cancer increases the risk of developing this condition (due to cancer-associated hypercoagulability). Budd-Chiari syndrome does not, however, explain this patient's jugular venous distention.
questions.hint: Consider the patient's history of thromboembolic events as a potential clue to the underlying pathology.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man presents with sudden onset of pleuritic chest pain, dyspnea, and mild hemoptysis. He had a 12-hour transatlantic flight earlier that week. He has no known history of cardiac or pulmonary disease. On examination, he appears anxious. Chest auscultation reveals normal breath sounds without crackles or wheezing (see lab result and reports).


Heart rate
115/min


Blood pressure
130/80 mmHg


Respiratory rate
26/min


Oxygen saturation
90% on room air




Test
Result
Normal Values


WBC
11.5 x 109/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 109/L



ECG: Right axis deviation and incomplete right bundle branch block
Chest X-ray: No consolidation or pleural effusion

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism manifests with sudden pleuritic chest pain, dyspnea, and hemoptysis due to obstruction of pulmonary arteries by thromboemboli. Prolonged immobilization, such as a long flight, increases the risk of deep venous thrombosis, which can embolize to the lungs. Clinical findings include tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypoxemia, reflecting hemodynamic and gas exchange disturbances. The ECG shows right axis deviation and incomplete right bundle branch block, indicating right ventricular strain from increased pulmonary vascular resistance. These clinical and diagnostic features align with pulmonary embolism.

Key learning point: The combination of chest pain, shortness of breath, hemoptysis, and specific ECG findings (right axis deviation, S1Q3T3 pattern, right bundle branch block) following prolonged immobility is highly suggestive of a pulmonary embolism.

B) INCORRECT:

Aortic dissection usually presents with tearing chest pain radiating to the back and may show a widened mediastinum on chest X-ray, which is absent here. The pleuritic pain, dyspnea, and hemoptysis suggest pulmonary pathology, not aortic dissection. The ECG findings indicate right heart strain, not typical of aortic dissection.

C) INCORRECT:

Pneumothorax typically presents with diminished or absent breath sounds and hyperresonance on percussion, which are not observed here. The chest X-ray would show a visceral pleural line, absent in this case. The ECG changes and risk factors also do not support pneumothorax.

D) INCORRECT:

Pneumonia often presents with crackles or bronchial breath sounds and chest X-ray consolidation, neither of which are present. The leukocytosis is nonspecific, and the absence of productive cough, fever, and radiographic evidence makes pneumonia unlikely.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old woman presents with sudden onset confusion, rapid breathing, and palpitations that started this morning. She has been bedridden for the past two weeks following a hip fracture. Her past medical history includes hypertension and mild cognitive impairment. She appears restless and has mild right-sided calf tenderness, but no chest pain. Chest auscultation reveals no rales or wheezes. A confirmatory imaging study has not been performed (see lab result).


Heart rate
112/min


Respiratory rate
24/min


Temperature
36.8°C


Oxygen saturation
90% on room air




Test
Result
Normal Values


D-dimer
1500 ng/mL
< 500 ng/mL


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Septic encephalopathy presents with altered mental status but typically includes fever, hypotension, and leukocytosis, which are absent. The elevated D-dimer and calf tenderness suggest a thromboembolic event rather than sepsis.

B) CORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism manifests with sudden onset confusion, tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypoxemia due to impaired pulmonary gas exchange. This patient, with recent immobilization after a hip fracture, is at high risk for venous thromboembolism. The elevated D-dimer level indicates increased fibrin degradation, suggesting thrombus formation and embolization. Mild calf tenderness suggests deep venous thrombosis, a common source of emboli. These clinical features align with a pulmonary embolism diagnosis.

Key learning point: In patients with recent immobility and acute onset of confusion and tachycardia, consider pulmonary embolism as a likely diagnosis due to the risk of venous thromboembolism.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute myocardial infarction often presents with chest pain, which is absent here. The elevated D-dimer suggests thrombus formation, not myocardial infarction. Calf tenderness and recent immobility indicate venous pathology rather than coronary occlusion.

D) INCORRECT:

Pneumonia typically presents with fever, productive cough, and abnormal lung sounds, such as rales or crackles. These findings are absent. The elevated D-dimer and calf tenderness suggest a thrombotic event rather than an infectious process.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man is on postoperative day 3 following knee surgery and presents with sudden shortness of breath and mild chest discomfort. He has obesity and has been ambulating minimally since the surgery. Examination shows normal breath sounds, swelling of the left calf, and no murmurs. Laboratory results reveal no significant leukocytosis (see report).


Heart rate
110/min


Blood pressure
125/80 mmHg


Temperature
37.2°C


Oxygen saturation
90% on room air


Chest X-ray: No acute infiltrates
Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism manifests with sudden shortness of breath, tachycardia, and hypoxemia due to ventilation-perfusion mismatch from an obstructed pulmonary artery. The patient's postoperative state, obesity, and limited mobility increase the risk of deep venous thrombosis (DVT), which can embolize to the lungs. Unilateral calf swelling suggests DVT. A normal chest X-ray is common in pulmonary embolism, as radiographic findings are often unremarkable. These clinical features align with the pathophysiology of embolization following DVT, leading to pulmonary embolism.

Key learning point: Sudden onset dyspnea and tachycardia in a post-surgical patient, especially after lower limb surgery, is highly suggestive of a pulmonary embolism due to increased risk of deep vein thrombosis and subsequent embolization.

B) INCORRECT:

Pneumonia typically presents with abnormal breath sounds and radiologic evidence of infiltrates, which are absent. Systemic signs like fever and leukocytosis are also common but not present. The postoperative state and calf swelling suggest a thromboembolic event rather than an infectious process.

C) INCORRECT:

Myocardial infarction often presents with severe, radiating chest pain, which is not described here. The absence of abnormal cardiac biomarkers, electrocardiogram changes, and pulmonary edema further reduces its likelihood. The patient's risk factors and symptoms suggest a thromboembolic event instead.

D) INCORRECT:

Spontaneous pneumothorax typically presents with diminished breath sounds and radiographic signs like a visible pleural line, which are not observed. The patient's risk factors, including recent surgery and calf swelling, indicate a thromboembolic process rather than pneumothorax.

questions.text:
A 69-year-old man develops acute shortness of breath, tachycardia, and mild chest discomfort two days after a laparoscopic colectomy for colon cancer. He reports bilateral calf tenderness. Physical examination shows clear lungs and mild left lower quadrant tenderness. Laboratory testing reveals no leukocytosis.


Heart rate
110/min


Blood pressure
135/78 mm Hg


Temperature
37.2°C


Oxygen saturation
90% on room air


Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atelectasis, a common postoperative complication, results from factors like anesthesia and reduced inspiratory effort. It typically presents with decreased breath sounds or dullness on percussion, which are absent here. The clear lung fields and bilateral calf tenderness suggest a different pathology.

B) CORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism manifests with acute dyspnea, tachycardia, and hypoxemia, particularly in postoperative patients with cancer due to increased thrombus formation risk. The presence of bilateral calf tenderness suggests deep vein thrombosis as the embolic source. The clear lung examination, despite significant hypoxemia, indicates a ventilation-perfusion mismatch typical of pulmonary embolism. This condition arises from embolic obstruction of the pulmonary vasculature, which does not cause pulmonary consolidation. The combination of these clinical features and the patient's postoperative status supports the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism.

Key learning point: Pulmonary embolism is a common cause of acute hypoxia in postoperative patients, especially after major surgeries, due to increased risk of venous thromboembolism.

C) INCORRECT:

Pneumonia often presents with abnormal lung findings such as crackles or signs of consolidation, which are not observed here. Additionally, the absence of fever and leukocytosis, along with bilateral calf tenderness, makes pneumonia unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Myocardial infarction typically presents with significant chest pain and signs of ischemia, which are not evident here. The mild chest discomfort and bilateral calf tenderness suggest a thromboembolic event rather than myocardial ischemia.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with sudden onset shortness of breath, chest pressure, and near-syncope. He has a history of recently diagnosed advanced colon cancer. Physical examination reveals jugular venous distension, a loud P2, and an occasional third heart sound. Despite intravenous fluid administration, he remains hypotensive (see lab result and reports).


Heart rate
130/min


Blood pressure
85/60 mmHg


Respiratory rate
28/min


Oxygen saturation
88% on room air




Test
Result
Normal Values


Troponin I
0.2 mg/L
0 - 0.4 mg/L



ECG: Sinus tachycardia and incomplete right bundle branch block
Transthoracic echocardiogram: Right ventricular dilation
CT pulmonary angiography: Large saddle pulmonary embolus

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inferior vena cava filters are used in patients with contraindications to anticoagulation or recurrent embolic events despite adequate anticoagulation. This patient requires immediate reperfusion due to acute hemodynamic instability from a large saddle pulmonary embolus. An IVC filter does not address the current embolus or provide rapid clot reduction, making it unsuitable for this situation.

B) INCORRECT:

Urgent surgical embolectomy is reserved for patients with massive pulmonary embolism who have contraindications to thrombolysis or fail to improve with thrombolytic therapy. It is invasive and carries significant operative risk. The patient's advanced colon cancer is not a contraindication to thrombolysis, and no other contraindications are mentioned. Therefore, surgical embolectomy is not the first-line treatment in this scenario.

C) CORRECT:

In massive pulmonary embolism with hemodynamic instability, systemic thrombolysis is indicated to rapidly resolve the thrombus and improve right ventricular function. This patient presents with hypotension, tachycardia, and right heart strain, confirmed by imaging showing a saddle pulmonary embolus. Intravenous alteplase promotes fibrinolysis by converting plasminogen to plasmin, dissolving the clot. Clinical guidelines support its use in massive pulmonary embolism to restore pulmonary circulation and stabilize hemodynamics, significantly reducing mortality risk.

Key learning point: In cases of massive pulmonary embolism with hemodynamic instability, thrombolytic therapy such as alteplase is the most appropriate treatment to rapidly dissolve the clot and restore hemodynamic stability.

D) INCORRECT:

Subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin is used for pulmonary embolism in hemodynamically stable patients. It has a slower onset of action, unsuitable for this patient with hemodynamic instability and a massive pulmonary embolism. Rapid reperfusion is essential, and LMWH does not provide the immediate intervention required.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department with acute onset severe shortness of breath, pleuritic chest pain, and lightheadedness after a day of inactivity. He has advanced osteoarthritis limiting ambulation. On arrival, he is diaphoretic (see report).


Heart rate
136/min


Blood pressure
82/46 mm Hg


Respiratory rate
32/min


Oxygen saturation
85% on room air


ECG: Signs of right ventricular strain
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?

choices.text: Placement of an inferior vena cava filter

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Massive pulmonary embolism manifests with hemodynamic instability, including hypotension, tachycardia, and right ventricular strain. This patient presents with severe shortness of breath, pleuritic chest pain, and shock-like hemodynamics, indicating a need for rapid restoration of pulmonary blood flow. Intravenous thrombolytic therapy dissolves the embolic clot, reducing right ventricular afterload and stabilizing hemodynamics. Prompt reperfusion in high-risk embolic events is crucial to reduce morbidity and mortality.

Key learning point: In cases of massive pulmonary embolism with hemodynamic instability, thrombolysis is the most appropriate initial treatment to rapidly dissolve the clot and restore circulation.

B) INCORRECT:

Urgent surgical embolectomy is reserved for massive pulmonary embolism when thrombolysis is contraindicated or fails. It is not the first-line treatment due to procedural risks and the need for specialized expertise. Systemic thrombolytic therapy is less invasive and can be promptly implemented in acute hemodynamic instability.

C) INCORRECT:

Subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin is used for hemodynamically stable pulmonary embolism due to its predictable dosing. However, in hemodynamically unstable cases, such as this one with profound hypotension and right ventricular strain, rapid and controllable anticoagulation is needed, typically achieved with intravenous unfractionated heparin.

D) INCORRECT:

Inferior vena cava filters prevent future emboli but do not address existing clot burden. They are used when anticoagulation is contraindicated or ineffective. In massive pulmonary embolism with hemodynamic compromise, immediate management should focus on reducing the current clot burden, such as with thrombolysis.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman at 19 weeks gestation presents to the clinic with a 2-day history of progressive shortness of breath and left-sided pleuritic chest pain. She reports recent prolonged air travel. Physical examination is normal. She expresses concern about fetal exposure from any diagnostic imaging (see lab results and report).


Heart rate
105/min


Blood pressure
110/70 mm Hg


Respiratory rate
24/min


Oxygen saturation
95% on room air




Test
Result

Normal Values



Hemoglobin
120 g/L
120 - 160 g/L


Platelet count
230 x 10⁹/L
150 - 400 x 10⁹/L


D-dimer
1,350 µg/L
< 500 µg/L



Chest X-ray: Normal
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT pulmonary angiography provides high-resolution imaging of the pulmonary vasculature but involves ionizing radiation and iodinated contrast, posing risks in pregnancy. The higher radiation dose to maternal breast tissue and fetal exposure concerns make it less suitable when alternatives like the V/Q scan, which have lower radiation risk, are available.

B) CORRECT:

In pregnant patients with suspected pulmonary embolism, minimizing fetal radiation exposure is crucial. A ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scan is preferred when the chest X-ray is normal, as it provides high diagnostic accuracy with lower radiation exposure to the fetus and maternal breast tissue compared to CT pulmonary angiography. The V/Q scan assesses ventilation and perfusion in the lungs, with mismatches indicating pulmonary embolism. The normal chest X-ray reduces the likelihood of non-diagnostic results, enhancing the V/Q scan's utility in this context.

Key learning point: In pregnant patients with suspected pulmonary embolism, a ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) lung scan is preferred over CT angiography due to lower radiation exposure to the fetus.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary angiography, though historically the gold standard for diagnosing pulmonary embolism, is invasive and involves high radiation doses. In pregnancy, minimizing fetal radiation exposure and avoiding procedural risks are priorities. The normal chest X-ray and the patient's concerns about fetal exposure favor less invasive imaging modalities.

D) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance pulmonary angiography avoids ionizing radiation but is not routinely used for suspected pulmonary embolism due to limited spatial resolution and challenges in visualizing distal vasculature. Gadolinium-based contrast agents, often used in MRPA, have an ambiguous safety profile in pregnancy, making this modality less suitable.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents with two days of worsening shortness of breath and sharp chest pain intensified by inspiration to the Outpatient Clinic. He was discharged one week ago following knee surgery. He has mild swelling of the right calf. Physical examination is otherwise normal. Pulmonary embolism is suspected.


Heart rate
110/min


Blood pressure
130/80 mm Hg


Respiratory rate
24/min


Oxygen saturation
94% on room air


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In acute pulmonary embolism, immediate anticoagulation is essential to prevent further clot propagation. Subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) is preferred in hemodynamically stable patients due to its predictable pharmacokinetics, ease of administration, and reduced need for monitoring compared to unfractionated heparin. LMWH provides effective anticoagulation through weight-based dosing, minimizing bleeding risk and lowering the incidence of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. It is particularly suitable for patients with risk factors for venous thromboembolism, such as recent orthopedic surgery, where immobilization and tissue injury contribute to clot formation. LMWH acts immediately, unlike oral warfarin, which requires bridging due to its delayed onset.

Key learning point: Low molecular weight heparin is the first-line treatment for the acute management of pulmonary embolism in a hemodynamically stable patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous unfractionated heparin is used for rapid anticoagulation in hemodynamically unstable patients or when quick reversibility is needed, such as in severe renal dysfunction. This patient is hemodynamically stable, with normal blood pressure and modest oxygen desaturation, making subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin more appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral warfarin is used for long-term anticoagulation but is unsuitable for immediate anticoagulation due to its delayed onset. It takes several days to deplete clotting factors and reach therapeutic levels. Initial warfarin therapy can also create a transient hypercoagulable state, posing additional risk if used alone.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous thrombolytic therapy is reserved for massive pulmonary embolism with hemodynamic instability, such as hypotension or shock. This patient is hemodynamically stable, with a blood pressure of 130/80 mm Hg. Recent knee surgery also increases bleeding risk, making thrombolysis inappropriate.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man presents on postoperative day 5 after a right total hip replacement to the clinic with acute onset of pleuritic chest pain and shortness of breath. He reports mild lower leg swelling for the last two days but has no fever or cough. The remainder of the examination is normal. You suspect a pulmonary embolism (see lab results and reports).


Heart rate
104/min


Blood pressure
130/80 mm Hg


Respiratory rate
22/min


Oxygen saturation
92% on room air




Test
Result
Normal Values



D-dimer
Positive
< 500 ng/mL


Creatinine
95 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L




Chest X-ray: Clear
Electrocardiogram: Normal sinus rhythm

Which diagnostic procedure is most definitive for confirming this suspicion?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scan is used when contrast-enhanced imaging is contraindicated, such as in renal insufficiency or contrast allergies. Although a clear chest X-ray improves V/Q scan interpretability, it provides an indirect assessment of pulmonary vasculature. Direct visualization of thrombi, as achieved with CT pulmonary angiography, is preferred for definitive diagnosis.

B) CORRECT:

The patient's symptoms, including pleuritic chest pain and shortness of breath following surgery, suggest a pulmonary embolism. Contrast-enhanced CT pulmonary angiography directly visualizes the pulmonary arteries, identifying intraluminal filling defects indicative of emboli. With normal renal function, the patient can safely undergo this procedure. Its high sensitivity and specificity make it the definitive diagnostic tool for pulmonary embolism.

Key learning point: In cases of suspected pulmonary embolism, a spiral CT-scan (CT pulmonary angiography) is the most definitive diagnostic test to confirm the presence of a PE.
Image Description:

CT chest (with IV contrast; axial plane)

Filling defects in the right and left descending pulmonary arteries (green overlay) represent pulmonary emboli.

SVC: superior vena cava; AA: ascending aorta; DA: descending aorta; MPA: main pulmonary artery; RPA: right pulmonary artery

C) INCORRECT:

Lower limb venous Doppler ultrasound detects deep venous thrombosis, a potential source of pulmonary emboli, but does not visualize pulmonary arteries. It supports an embolic event when a clot is found but cannot confirm embolization in the lungs. Direct pulmonary imaging is necessary for definitive diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) can show indirect signs of pulmonary embolism, such as right ventricular strain, but does not visualize pulmonary thrombi. It is useful for assessing cardiac function but lacks the direct visualization needed to confirm a pulmonary embolism.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents with sudden onset shortness of breath and hemoptysis two days after an open cholecystectomy. He reports mild right-sided chest discomfort. Physical examination shows no calf edema (see lab result and reports).


Heart rate
112/min


Blood pressure
125/75 mmHg


Respiratory rate
28/min


Oxygen saturation
89% on room air




Test
Result
Normal Values


Hemoglobin
110 g/L
130 - 170 g/L



Chest X-ray: Normal cardiac silhouette; no obvious consolidation
ECG: Sinus tachycardia without ischemic changes

Which diagnostic test is most appropriate to confirm the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The patient's sudden onset of dyspnea, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypoxemia, and hemoptysis following surgery suggests a pulmonary embolism. CT pulmonary angiography is the preferred diagnostic test as it provides direct visualization of the pulmonary arteries, identifying filling defects caused by thromboemboli. It offers high sensitivity and specificity, rapid acquisition, and is noninvasive, making it ideal for confirming pulmonary embolism in this clinical context.

Key learning point: In a postoperative patient with sudden-onset shortness of breath and hemoptysis, CT pulmonary angiography is the most appropriate test to diagnose pulmonary embolism.

B) INCORRECT:

Conventional pulmonary angiography is invasive and carries risks such as contrast-induced nephropathy and vascular injury. CT pulmonary angiography is preferred due to its noninvasive nature, rapid acquisition, and comparable accuracy in diagnosing pulmonary embolism.

C) INCORRECT:

D-dimer is sensitive for thrombus formation but lacks specificity, especially post-surgery, where levels are often elevated due to inflammation and coagulation. It is not suitable for confirming pulmonary embolism in high-suspicion cases, as it can lead to false positives.

D) INCORRECT:

While useful for detecting deep venous thrombosis, this test does not directly visualize pulmonary emboli. The absence of calf edema reduces the likelihood of a lower extremity DVT, and ultrasound findings would not confirm pulmonary embolism.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old woman presents to the clinic with sudden onset shortness of breath and mild pleuritic chest pain that began several hours ago. She is a non-smoker with a history of well-controlled hypertension. Physical examination shows mild tachypnea but no jugular venous distension or lower-extremity edema. She is hemodynamically stable with no right heart strain or contraindications to anticoagulation (see lab results and report).


Heart rate
100/min


Blood pressure
130/80 mm Hg


Respiratory rate
22/min


Oxygen saturation
96% on room air




Test
Result
Normal Values



D-dimer
750 ng/mL
< 500 ng/mL


Creatinine
95 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L


Estimated glomerular filtration rate
65 mL/min
> 60 mL/min



CT pulmonary angiogram: Multiple segmental pulmonary emboli
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Placement of an inferior vena cava filter

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous alteplase is reserved for massive pulmonary embolism with hemodynamic instability, such as shock or significant right ventricular dysfunction. This patient is hemodynamically stable, and the risks of thrombolysis, including major bleeding, outweigh the benefits in stable cases.

B) INCORRECT:

Inferior vena cava filters are indicated for patients with contraindications to anticoagulation or recurrent emboli despite anticoagulation. This patient can safely receive anticoagulation, and routine use of an IVC filter in such cases does not provide additional benefit and may pose risks like filter thrombosis and migration.

C) CORRECT:

In hemodynamically stable patients with pulmonary embolism, systemic anticoagulation is crucial to prevent clot propagation. Low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) is preferred due to its predictable pharmacokinetics, ease of subcutaneous administration, and reduced need for laboratory monitoring. It provides effective anticoagulation with a favorable safety profile, minimizing the risk of major bleeding. LMWH also facilitates a smooth transition to oral anticoagulants for long-term management.

Key learning point: In the acute management of pulmonary embolism, enoxaparin is a commonly used initial anticoagulant due to its rapid onset and ease of use, especially in the inpatient setting.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous unfractionated heparin is suitable for hemodynamically unstable patients or those with significant renal impairment. It requires continuous infusion and frequent monitoring, making it less ideal for stable patients with adequate renal function, like this patient. LMWH or direct oral anticoagulants are more appropriate due to their predictable pharmacokinetics and simplified dosing.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of shortness of breath and sharp, stabbing chest pain that worsens with deep inspiration. She has been using oral contraceptives for the past year. She is tachypneic (see report).


Heart rate
110/min


Blood pressure
115/70 mm Hg


Respiratory rate
22/min


Oxygen saturation
96% on room air


Chest radiograph: Unremarkable
Which of the following is the most appropriate test to confirm the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance angiography of the pulmonary vasculature
Contrast-enhanced CT of the pulmonary vasculature

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The D-dimer assay is sensitive for thrombus formation but lacks specificity, making it unsuitable for confirming pulmonary embolism in patients with high pre-test probability, such as those with risk factors like oral contraceptive use. It does not localize emboli or provide anatomical detail necessary for therapeutic decisions.

B) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) of the pulmonary vasculature is limited by longer acquisition times and decreased sensitivity for smaller emboli. It is less practical in acute settings due to these limitations and potential contraindications, making it less suitable for confirming pulmonary embolism in this context.

C) CORRECT:

Contrast-enhanced CT of the pulmonary vasculature (CTPA) is highly sensitive and specific for detecting pulmonary embolism, as it directly visualizes thromboembolic material in the pulmonary arteries. It provides high-resolution images for precise localization of emboli, crucial for confirming the diagnosis in patients with sudden dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain, especially with risk factors like oral contraceptive use. CTPA allows rapid diagnostic confirmation and evaluation of alternative thoracic pathology, facilitating timely management without additional invasive procedures.

Key learning point: Chest CT angiography is the most definitive test to diagnose pulmonary embolism, especially in patients with sudden onset of shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain who are at risk, such as those using oral contraceptives.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary angiography, though historically the gold standard for diagnosing pulmonary embolism, is invasive and carries procedural risks. Noninvasive imaging like CTPA is preferred for stable patients, as it minimizes risks such as contrast-induced nephrotoxicity and vascular injury while providing high diagnostic accuracy.

questions.text: You are seeing a 54-year-old woman in the emergency department who presents with a 1-day history of sharp chest pain and shortness of breath. Her temperature is 37.8°C, pulse is 110/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 86/70 mm Hg. CT angiography of the chest reveals a large embolus in the right pulmonary artery. She receives pharmacologic treatment with a tissue plasminogen activator. Six hours later, she develops right-sided weakness and slurred speech. Laboratory studies show elevated prothrombin and partial thromboplastin times, with a normal bleeding time. A CT scan of the head demonstrates a large, left-sided intracranial hemorrhage. Which one of the following is the most appropriate agent to reverse her acquired coagulopathy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Antifibrinolytics such as aminocaproic acid and tranexamic acid can reverse the effects of tPA by inhibiting the activation of plasminogen, thereby interfering with plasmin formation. Without plasmin, fibrin is no longer degraded and further hemorrhage can be slowed or prevented. In addition to antifibrinolytics, current guidelines also recommend administering fresh frozen plasma or cryoprecipitate in cases of bleeding due to thrombolytic therapy.

Key learning point: Aminocaproic acid, an antifibrinolytic agent, is used to reverse tPA-induced coagulopathy by inhibiting plasmin formation and preventing further fibrin degradation.

B) INCORRECT:

Desmopressin is used to treat hemophilia A and von Willebrand disease types 1 and 2 because it stimulates the release of Factor VIII/vWF from Weibel–Palade bodies in endothelial cells. Desmopressin does not reverse the effects of the tissue plasminogen activator administered to this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients who develop a major active bleed from significant liver disease or with the use of a vitamin K antagonist (e.g., warfarin) should receive intravenous vitamin K, which improves the hepatic synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors (factor II, VII, IX, and X). Vitamin K, however, does not reverse the effects of tPA, which is the cause of bleeding in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Protamine is a cationic peptide that forms a stable pair with anionic heparin or low molecular weight heparin. Protamine sulfate is administered intravenously to reverse bleeding due to heparin overdose. Protamine sulfate does not reverse the thrombolytic effects of tPA.

E) INCORRECT:

A tPA facilitates thrombolysis by converting plasminogen to plasmin. The administration of plasmin would, therefore, enhance the effects of tPA, not reverse them.
questions.hint: This patient with a confirmed diagnosis of a pulmonary embolism was treated with a tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) and subsequently developed bleeding as a complication of therapy. Tissue plasminogen activators (e.g., alteplase) increase thrombolysis by converting plasminogen to plasmin, which directly dissolves the thrombus by degrading fibrin.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 34 weeks' gestation comes to your clinic with a 1-day history of shortness of breath, dry cough, and chest pain. Her pulse is 112/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 108/78 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 90%. On examination, she has jugular venous distention and bilateral pitting edema below the knees, worse on the right side. There is dullness to percussion over the right lung base. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Myocardial infarction (MI) can manifest with acute-onset chest pain and dyspnea. However, MI is unlikely in a young patient, like this 28-year-old woman, and it would not explain this patient's dry cough and asymmetrical leg edema.

B) INCORRECT:

Pneumonia can cause chest pain, dyspnea, hypoxia, cough, and unilateral dullness to percussion (from consolidation and/or a parapneumonic effusion). However, this patient lacks additional common manifestations of pneumonia such as fever, productive cough, and malaise. Moreover, pneumonia would not explain this patient's JVD and asymmetrical leg edema.

C) INCORRECT:

Spontaneous pneumothorax can manifest with acute-onset chest pain, dyspnea, tachypnea, cough, hypoxia, and tachycardia. Jugular venous distention can also develop in cases of tension pneumothorax. However, pneumothorax would result in hyperresonance to percussion of the affected side, not dullness, and would not explain this patient's asymmetrical leg edema.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute pericarditis can cause acute-onset chest pain and JVD (if a large, associated pericardial effusion has compromised right ventricular filling). However, pericarditis would not explain this patient's asymmetrical leg edema, dry cough, and unilateral pleural effusion.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical findings should raise concern for pulmonary embolism (PE). Pregnancy and the postpartum period are risk factors for the development of venous thrombosis and subsequent PE. During pregnancy, compression of the venous system due to an enlarged uterus can result in venous stasis, one of the three components of the Virchow triad. Another component is hypercoagulability, which is classically seen in pregnant women due to an increase in coagulation factors and decreased levels of protein S. In addition, endothelial damage may occur during labor, thereby increasing the risk of thrombosis during the postpartum period.

Establishing the diagnosis of PE during pregnancy can be challenging because many manifestations overlap with normal pregnancy-related changes (e.g., dyspnea, leg swelling, tachycardia, decreased blood pressure). In this patient, features that can help to distinguish PE from normal pregnancy findings include the presence of JVD, asymmetric leg edema, and unilateral dullness to percussion of the lung, which suggests pleural effusion. In patients with PE, pleural effusion can occur if the occluded pulmonary artery causes tissue ischemia (i.e., pulmonary infarction), which leads to increased permeability of pulmonary vessels.

Key learning point: Pregnancy increases the risk of pulmonary embolism due to venous stasis and hypercoagulability, and PE should be suspected in pregnant patients with acute dyspnea, chest pain, hypoxemia, and signs of unilateral leg swelling or pleural effusion.
questions.hint: This patient presents with acute dyspnea, chest pain, hypoxemia, tachycardia, signs of right ventricular dysfunction (jugular venous distention), and features of deep venous thrombosis (asymmetrical leg edema).

questions.text: You are seeing a 25-year-old woman in the emergency department with sudden-onset pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea. She reports pain and swelling in her left lower leg over the past several days. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her blood pressure is 105/70 mm Hg, heart rate is 115/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. Lung auscultation is clear. Cardiac examination reveals a regular rhythm. She has 2+ edema of the left lower extremity. Electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance angiography of the chest.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A transthoracic echocardiogram may show evidence of right heart strain in a patient with massive or submassive PE, but it is not a diagnostic test for PE.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's pretest probability of PE is high, as indicated by a Wells score of 7.5. The criteria for calculating a Wells score are listed below. This patient meets the first three criteria.

• Signs and symptoms of deep-vein thrombosis (3 points)
• Likelihood of an alternative diagnosis that is less than or equal to that of PE (3 points)
• Heart rate >100 beats per minute (1.5 points)
• Immobilization for ≥3 days or surgery in the past 4 weeks (1.5 points)
• Previous deep-vein thrombosis or PE (1.5 points)
• Hemoptysis (1 point)
• Malignancy treated in the past 6 months (1 point)

A cumulative Wells score >6 is associated with high risk for PE. The most appropriate diagnostic test in high-risk cases is CT pulmonary angiography.

Key learning point: In a patient with a high pretest probability of pulmonary embolism, the diagnostic test of choice is CT pulmonary angiography.

C) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance angiography has insufficient sensitivity for diagnosing PE.

D) INCORRECT:

In a patient with a high pretest probability of PE, a normal D-dimer result does not rule out PE.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient’s presentation is much more consistent with PE than with myocardial ischemia. Therefore, myocardial perfusion stress testing is inappropriate.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs and symptoms that are consistent with pulmonary embolism (PE).

questions.text: You are seeing a 67-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department with a 3-hour history of left-sided chest pain. He returned from a business trip to London 1 day ago. His medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He has a 30-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. His temperature is 36.9°C, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 138/92 mm Hg. A ventilation-perfusion radionuclide scan shows a segmental mismatch between lung ventilation and perfusion. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of his current condition?

choices.text: Intimal wall weakening of the thoracic aorta.
Plaque formation in a coronary artery.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Fragments of deep vein thromboses (DVTs) formed in the iliac veins can embolize first to the heart via the vena cava and then to the pulmonary vasculature, resulting in pulmonary embolism (PE). The severity of PE depends on the number and size of the emboli occluding the pulmonary vasculature. Long-distance air travel is a strong risk factor for DVTs because it involves prolonged immobilization and venous stasis in the lower limbs. Other risk factors for DVT include advanced age and a history of smoking. V/Q scans show areas of normal ventilation mixed with perfusion failure and may aid in the diagnosis of PE.

DVT most commonly occurs in the iliac veins and other proximal deep veins of the lower extremities (e.g., femoral and popliteal vein).

Key learning point: Pulmonary embolism most often results from thrombi originating in the deep veins of the lower extremities, especially after prolonged immobilization.
Image Description:

Nuclear medicine ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scan of a patient with a recent history of bilateral pleuritic chest pain; A: ventilation image (20.1 mCi of Xenon-133 gas), posterior projection; B: perfusion image (4.1 mCi of Technetium-99m-labeled macroaggregated albumin), posterior projection

The ventilation image shows uniform distribution of gas throughout the lungs, indicating normal ventilation. The perfusion image shows bilateral wedge-shaped defects (examples indicated by red overlay) from pulmonary emboli. Mismatched perfusion defects may also be seen in a variety of other settings, including venoocclusive disease, pulmonary artery obstruction from tumor, and radiation therapy.

H: heart

B) INCORRECT:

Intimal wall weakening of the thoracic aorta predisposes to aortic dissection. Patients with aortic dissection typically present with a severe, “tearing” chest pain that radiates to the back. Tachycardia and tachypnea may also be present. However, aortic dissection would not explain a V/Q mismatch.

C) INCORRECT:

Destruction of pulmonary acini leads to the formation and eventual rupture of emphysematous bullae, resulting in spontaneous pneumothorax. Spontaneous pneumothorax is strongly associated with a history of smoking and can manifest with symptoms similar to those seen in this patient (chest pain, tachycardia, and tachypnea). However, pneumothorax would not explain a V/Q mismatch.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with bacterial pneumonia classically present with chest pain, tachycardia, and tachypnea. Pneumonia can also result in V/Q mismatch due to impaired ventilation (caused by increased intra-alveolar fluid in some parts of the lungs). However, this patient lacks other typical features of bacterial pneumonia, such as a productive cough, high fever, and malaise.

E) INCORRECT:

Coronary artery plaques can lead to cardiac ischemia and myocardial infarctions, which classically manifest with retrosternal chest pain, tachycardia, and tachypnea. This patient is at increased risk for coronary artery disease because of his smoking history, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus. However, myocardial infarction would not explain a V/Q mismatch.
questions.hint: Combined with poor perfusion on a ventilation/perfusion scan (V/Q scan), symptoms of chest pain, tachycardia, and tachypnea suggest pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: You are seeing a previously healthy 35-year-old woman in the emergency department with sudden onset of difficulty breathing that began upon waking this morning. She also reports chest pain. She has no history of serious illness and her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her temperature is 38.0°C, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. Oxygen saturation on room air is 93%. Physical examination is unremarkable. ECG shows a regular sinus rhythm. Chest x-ray is normal. In addition to oxygen supplementation, which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in the work-up of pulmonary embolism?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's Wells score for PE is 3, meaning that PE is more likely than other diagnoses but that no other Wells criteria for PE (e.g., tachycardia, hemoptysis, clinical symptoms of DVT) are fulfilled (see “Wells criteria for pulmonary embolism” table). This patient's modified Wells score indicates that PE is unlikely (i.e., a modified Wells score ≤ 4). In patients with suspected PE but a pretest probability of an unlikely diagnosis, clinical assessment should be followed by D-dimer measurement because normal D-dimer values rule out the diagnosis. In patients with elevated D-dimer values, further testing with CTPA or V/Q scan is required to confirm or exclude PE.

Key learning point: In patients with low pretest probability for pulmonary embolism, a normal D-dimer test effectively rules out the diagnosis without the need for imaging.
Image Description:

CTPA: computer tomography pulmonary angiogram
PE: pulmonary embolism
PERC: Pulmonary Embolism Rule-out Criteria
PTP: pretest probability
RV: right ventricle
V/Q scan: ventilation/perfusion scan

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary angiography is no longer routinely used to diagnose PE and is only recommended if a patient has a high pretest probability of PE and CT angiography is unavailable.

C) INCORRECT:

Ventilation and perfusion scintigraphy (V/Q scan) can be used to diagnose patients with a high pretest probability of PE, but who have contraindications to CT angiography. A perfusion failure in a normally ventilated pulmonary area (mismatch) is highly suggestive of PE.

D) INCORRECT:

CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA) is the best definitive diagnostic test for PE. This contrast-enhanced imaging study is both sensitive and specific in diagnosing intraluminal filling defects in the pulmonary arteries but is also associated with certain risks (e.g., contrast-induced nephropathy). CTPA would be the next step in management for a hemodynamically stable patient with a high pretest probability of PE.

E) INCORRECT:

The A-a gradient, obtained from an arterial blood gas analysis, can be used to help identify the underlying pathophysiology of hypoxemia (e.g., shunt, V/Q mismatch, etc). While the PaO2 is typically low in patients with PE, this is neither a sensitive nor specific test and is not considered useful for the diagnosis of PE.
questions.hint: In patients with suspected PE, externally validated decision tools such as the Wells score should be used to assess the pretest probability.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with dyspnea that began 4 hours ago. She reports no chest pain but has mild anxiety. She underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy 2 weeks ago and has been ambulating normally since discharge. Vital signs are BP, 125/75; P, 105; R, 20; oxygen saturation, 94% on room air. Physical examination shows tachycardia but no lower extremity swelling or tenderness. Chest x-ray shows clear lung fields. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bedside echocardiography is primarily used for hemodynamically unstable patients with suspected massive pulmonary embolism or for severity assessment. A different first step in management is indicated in this stable patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Arterial blood gas analysis has limited utility in the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism (PE). This test is not the most appropriate next step in this patient with intermediate pretest probability for PE.

C) INCORRECT:

Discharge would be inappropriate without ruling out pulmonary embolism in this patient with intermediate pretest probability. Tachycardia and dyspnea in the context of recent surgery warrant further evaluation.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has an intermediate pretest probability for pulmonary embolism based on Wells criteria (recent surgery 1.5 points, tachycardia 1.5 points, total 3 points = intermediate risk). For intermediate pretest probability, D-dimer is the appropriate initial test. If D-dimer is elevated, confirmatory imaging with CT pulmonary angiography is indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

CT pulmonary angiography is indicated for patients with high pretest probability of pulmonary embolism or those with intermediate pretest probability and elevated D-dimer. This patient has intermediate pretest probability, making D-dimer the appropriate initial test.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer presents with sudden-onset dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain. She underwent chemotherapy 3 months ago and has had restricted movement for two weeks due to a leg fracture. Vital signs are BP, 130/85; P, 105; R, 24; oxygen saturation, 92% on room air. Her Wells score is 7.5. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Echocardiogram is used for prognostic assessment and evaluating right ventricular dysfunction in patients with confirmed pulmonary embolism, and it can be used before diagnostic confirmation in hemodynamically unstable patients. This patient does not have an established diagnosis, and she is hemodynamically stable.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary angiography is indicated for inconclusive CT pulmonary angiography findings and high level of suspicion for pulmonary embolism or for patients who are candidates for concomitant endovascular treatment. Pulmonary angiography is more invasive than first-line imaging and requires selective injection of contrast dye into the pulmonary arteries during fluoroscopic examination. It is not the initial imaging test for hemodynamically stable patients with high pretest probability of pulmonary embolism.

C) INCORRECT:

Ventilation/perfusion scan is an alternative to CT pulmonary angiography but is primarily indicated when there are contraindications to iodinated contrast. CT pulmonary angiography is preferred when available because it is faster and more readily available and can identify alternative diagnoses.

D) INCORRECT:

D-dimer testing is not indicated in patients with high pretest probability of pulmonary embolism (Wells score ≥ 7). In patients with high pretest probability, confirmatory imaging should be obtained directly.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – With a Wells score of 7.5, this patient has a high pretest probability of pulmonary embolism. High pretest probability mandates confirmatory imaging, and CT pulmonary angiography is the preferred diagnostic test for pulmonary embolism in hemodynamically stable patients due to its high sensitivity and specificity.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with acute dyspnea following a 6-hour flight. She has a history of breast cancer treated with chemotherapy 8 months ago. Vital signs are BP, 82/55; P, 118; R, 30; oxygen saturation, 86% on room air. She appears anxious and diaphoretic. ECG shows sinus tachycardia with new right bundle branch block. Point-of-care echocardiography shows severe right ventricular dilation with septal flattening. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has massive pulmonary embolism with hemodynamic instability and right heart failure, evidenced by severe right ventricular dilation and septal flattening. The most immediate life-saving intervention is urgent reperfusion with thrombolysis, which should begin immediately if there are no absolute contraindications.

B) INCORRECT:

Anticoagulation is important for pulmonary embolism (PE) treatment but is not the most immediate intervention for massive PE with hemodynamic instability.

C) INCORRECT:

Large-volume fluid resuscitation can worsen right ventricular function in massive pulmonary embolism. Limited fluid therapy (≤ 500 mL) is recommended for patients with evidence of low intravascular volume to avoid volume overload.

D) INCORRECT:

While CT pulmonary angiography is the gold standard for pulmonary embolism (PE) diagnosis, this patient is hemodynamically unstable and has echocardiographic evidence of massive PE. Delaying definitive treatment to obtain confirmatory imaging is inappropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

While mechanical ventilation may be considered for hypoxemic respiratory failure in massive pulmonary embolism, it does not address the underlying pulmonary vascular obstruction. Urgent reperfusion therapy remains the priority to restore pulmonary circulation and hemodynamic stability.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute chest pain and dyspnea. He has a history of lung cancer and received his last chemotherapy treatment 3 weeks ago. A week ago, he underwent open reduction and internal fixation of a fractured radius after a fall. His vital signs are BP, 85/55; P, 120; oxygen saturation, 88% on room air.
